This hit me more than I thought it would I was an undiagnosed adhd child, filled with creativity all the time. I wrote fictions and poems very early, I had such a vivid imagination, capable of living so many thrilling adventures in my head. Once I was 10, I started to write a sci-fi work. It wasn't good, of course, and some concepts were not believable. But I think that's OK at 10, I didn't plan on getting published or anything. One of my parents read my text, pointed every detail, reworking my ideas under their scope, even suggested a change of name. I was disowned and belittled, and this kind of pattern kept on happening throughout the years. The thing is, my school teachers were on their end pleased with my creativity and my passion for imagining stories   I could felt my imagination and my creativity fading away.  Now as an adult I'm devoid of it and it hurts. I used to write pretty badass poems too. Feeling drained out of something as magical as imagination and creativity feels dreading s

I don't know if I am naturally creative or not.  To some extent I favored Math and Science but I enjoy reading History and Historical fiction.  Education was my life so if I criticize education at all it is sort of like committing suicide.  The only friends I ever had valued public education and were active in class discussions and such.  But I have to complain when teachers encouraged the topic like "changing the Economy" which I consider something approaching creativity in Economics, Math and Statistics.  No business, government agency or political candidate wants my "creative" opinion on the Economy.  If they want a projection or information they want something realistic, substantive and real.  When I rejected "creative economics"  I was basically criticized by Education and laughed at by some Professors or maybe worse.  So I guess I have to ask the question as to whether education was trying to kill me.  I simply did not know what changing thee Economic system meant without learning the rules.  I'm glad I started out learning the rules of Economics and sticking to the rules of Math and Statistics and I don't look back at this despite my rejection.  Sure, you can talk about creativity in English or Art but I knew a woman who taught Home Economics and I did not notice Creativity from her even in a recipe or a meal.  With all respect, I've had a lot of anxiety since graduation over creative Economics and this should not be the problem.  When I rejected creativity in Economics some teachers did encourage me to study English. And if I eventually decide to return to University and study English as ordered by my teachers, I will be glad that Creative Economics no longer gives me a headache and I can finally move forward with my life.

I'm probably 18 years late to this conversation, but i need to say a couple of things:  1. Most people i see have a very flawed understanding of what creativity is, and what is needed to develop it. 2. Creativity feeds on knowledge. Schools give you that. You can't be very creative in an area if you know nothing about it (source: I'm a mathematician, history of math is plaged with examples of this) 3. It is a very bold assumption to say "schools kill creativity" without taking into account the several differences amongs educational systems, or even schools in the same region, for that matter. It does make a catchy slogan, I'll give it that...  I don't think people are going to read this, I'll leave here anyway...

He excels at any sport he tries, heâ€™s an incredibly fast runner, amazing coordination. Heâ€™s only 6 years old but he has very toned calves, quads, and even abs. This kid is a natural athlete. But instead heâ€™s been put on medication and made to sit at a desk all day. I think itâ€™s so sad.   My kid also has ADHD but sheâ€™s clumsy and uncoordinated and her hyperactivity usually manifests as rolling around on the ground.   But in this otherâ€™s kidâ€™s situation his energy is an asset. ğŸ¯ Key points for quick navigation:  00:27 The conference themes include human creativity, uncertainty about the future, and the extraordinary capacities of children. 01:55 Education is crucial as it prepares future generations for an unpredictable world, yet we don't know what the future holds. 03:21 Creativity should be valued as equally important as literacy in education systems. 05:22 Fear of mistakes stifles creativity; children are naturally willing to take risks, but education often teaches them to fear being wrong. 06:58 Shakespeare was a child once and experienced education, highlighting that creativity can exist alongside structured learning. 08:35 Educational systems worldwide prioritize subjects like math and languages over arts, diminishing creativity in the process. 10:35 The current education system is designed to produce university professors and places limited value on diverse talents and creativity. 12:57 Academic inflation devalues degrees; the education system needs to adapt to a rapidly changing world and embrace diverse intelligences. 16:58 Gillian Lynne's story exemplifies how recognizing and nurturing a child's unique talents can lead to great success and fulfillment. 17:57 Our education system should nurture the full spectrum of human capacities to solve future challenges, focusing on creative possibilities. watching this for a course in late 2024 (first having an existential crisis that this was posted 17 years ago) and reading comments spanning years between then and now, where people have observed the passage of time, and how little has changed - I think its safe to say that we're probably worse now than ever. When he says "we are raising university professors" - I believe we've gone one step further; we're now only testing the university graduates who have become professors to see if can they train 30+ children at once to regurgitate their state's curriculum on a standardized test to prove that the schools are doing their job.  I think in an ideal world, students would work on individually selected, special interest projects to work on throughout a school year, and then spend time as a group learning concepts to apply within those projects. In an age where all knowledge (and disinformation) is readily available at our fingertips, teaching children to self educate through sourcing accurate information, thinking critically about a problem, applying research and skills they've learned in an imaginative, novel, pragmatic or effective way successfully helps creates adults who can thrive in any environment.   There is a great Star Trek: Next Gen episode about an alien society who has (essentially) a pre-smart phone device that connects them to everyone from their home planet as well as a massive super computer knowledge base - they originally board the Enterprise under the guise of upgrading their computer systems, but are actually there to upgrade their own. Despite having all the necessary information the Bynars run into issues that bottleneck them and cause problems - the Enterprise crew eventually realizes what is happening and devises a solution to their problem that the Bynars' overlooked, having missed the forest for the trees. Learning only a set of solutions, learning only to pass a test doesn't teach you how to THINK, only how to repeat answers or procedures that you've already been taught.   Until we teach the skills necessary to search, self educate, think critically and creatively, and apply those principles and techniques to problems that interest the student, those without a natural capacity for those skills will be struggling as adults. Running into people who have never learned those skills in the wild is always painful and leaves me questioning how those types have survived (or gone unnoticed as ... "ineffective" in their workplaces...) because for me, running into a problem I don't immediately know the answer to is an exciting chance to deep dive and hoard some more knowledge, and maybe even learn something unexpected that could help me improve other processes or solutions in unrelated parts of my life.

I do think that school kills creativity. First because my sister made a technical artistic school, and today she have difficulty to be more spontaneous in art. And me, i never made an art school, so i may not have a lot of technical abilities, but i have more spontanteity and creativity. So art school are great, but it shouldn't enclose in too much technics, but also encourage pure creativity. And second, i do think that in french school, art aren't taken seriously. We had only 1 hour of artistic course and 1 h of music per week, and no one really worked during them, everyone was talking and the teacher weren't involved too. It was really boring. Not motivating (while i'm an artist myself). And the others class were about history, geography, mathematics, french....all that was boring for me, and in french school, the only thing you do, it's to sit down, listen during hours, and have homework to do. Nothing that encourage individuality or creativity. I say that, because i saw that in usa, music and arts + groups/club school, did encourage projects, creativity, and art is from a higher level. So yes, in france, arts aren't major at school, and if you want to became an artist, they say to you that it wouldn't work, and they put you in secretary school, instead to give you a chance to express your individuality. I deeply believe that school don't always work, and that finally we don't need to go in school, but to learn what we really WANT to learn. For me i would have love to learn more poetry, philosophy, art, music. I think that school shouldn't program us, but that we should program things that correspond to what we really need.

In the 1930's the condition we know now as ADHD was considered to be a moral failing or a defect in character and generally treated with violence and when that didnt work the children were written off. Gillian probably did have ADHD she also was lucky enough to have parents who were attentive enough to notice, had the means to see specialists and to put her into a dance school. Probably many more Gillians were just flushed down the toilet (figuratively speaking). Agree the education system is not suited to most kids but please dont dismiss a known biological condition like ADHD like that. It sounds very quippy but its actually quite dangerous. Nowadays Gillian wouldnt be given pills, shed have been left on a waiting list for 2-3 years while her parents struggled to find accomodations for her at school. When she did get assessed she probably would have been rejected because her behaviour wasnt disruptive enough. A huge percentage of ADHD females are only diagnosed in adulthood as they tend to turn the hyperactivity in on themselves and receive more pressure to mask the symptoms. If she was lucky enough to be diagnosed in childhood, they would indeed treat her with medication because if she has ADHD they know that there are certain chemicals such as dopamine that the ADHD brain struggles to produce. She still would have been a dancer - quite possibly an even better one. Definitely a happier one and not carrying around any shame or stigma from growing up "not good enough". Myself I was missed, as they just didnt know that much about it yet and was only diagnosed in my 40's. It saved my life.

Here are the knowledge objects extracted from the content:  ### Title: Creativity as important as literacy in education  - Fact: Education meant to prepare children for the future, but the future is unpredictable.  - Situation: Education systems worldwide undervalue creativity and the arts.    - Cause: Education systems designed for the industrial era to meet needs of the job market.  - Approach: Treat creativity as equally important as literacy in education. Nurture arts, dance, drama, music daily as core subjects, not extras.   ### Title: Mistakes and risk-taking foster creativity  - Fact: Children naturally take chances and try new things.  - Situation: Adults become frightened of being wrong and making mistakes.  - Cause: School systems stigmatize and penalize errors rather than rewarding imagination.  - Approach: Encourage experimentation. Let children explore ideas without fear of being wrong.  ### Title: Rethink narrow conceptions of intelligence  - Fact: Intelligence is diverse, dynamic, and distinct in each person.  - Situation: Academic ability prized above all other talents.  - Cause: Education systems designed to produce academics and reward book smarts.  - Approach: Value all expressions of intelligence - kinesthetic, musical, spatial, interpersonal etc. Identify and nurture each child's distinct abilities.  ### Title: Nurture the whole child  - Fact: Standard education focuses heavily on the brain, less on the body.  - Situation: Children taught to sit still and control physical expression.   - Cause: Belief that mind and body are separate, and mental work is superior.  - Approach: Educate the whole child - heart, mind, body and spirit. Let children move, dance, play. Physical expression and creativity go hand in hand.

The main pieces of advice given in the video are as follows:      Value Creativity Equally: The speaker suggests that creativity should be given the same importance as literacy in education systems. He believes that creativity is a fundamental skill required to navigate an uncertain and rapidly changing future.      Embrace Mistakes: The speaker encourages embracing mistakes and taking chances. He emphasizes that being afraid of making mistakes stifles creativity, and that original ideas often come from the willingness to try new things, even if they might be wrong at first.      Rethink Intelligence: The speaker challenges the traditional concept of intelligence that places academic subjects at the top of the hierarchy. He advocates for recognizing diverse forms of intelligence, such as artistic, kinesthetic, and creative abilities, which are often overlooked in traditional education.      Foster Interdisciplinary Thinking: The speaker highlights the importance of interdisciplinary thinking, where different ways of seeing and understanding the world intersect. He suggests that creative breakthroughs often come from the interaction of various disciplines.      Nurture Children's Talents: The speaker believes that all children possess unique talents and capacities for innovation. He suggests that educational systems should nurture these talents rather than suppress them.      Encourage Movement and Expression: The speaker notes that children often express themselves through movement and action. He argues that arts, like dance and music, should be given equal importance in education as traditional subjects, as they engage different aspects of human intelligence.      Prepare for an Unpredictable Future: The speaker emphasizes that the future is uncertain, and current education systems must prepare students for jobs and challenges that are yet to emerge. Focusing solely on traditional subjects might not adequately equip students for what lies ahead.      Celebrate Human Imagination: The speaker underscores the importance of human imagination in solving future problems. He believes that fostering creativity and imagination will contribute to a brighter and more innovative future.

Society and culture have a profound influence on education, shaping its goals, values, and practices.  The social environment encompasses aspects such as family, community, government, economy, and social values. The family is the earliest educational environment for children, and parents and family members have a significant influence on their educational attitudes and values. The community and government's education policies and resource allocation also have far-reaching effects on education. Economic factors, such as the job market and career opportunities, also influence students' attitudes and goals towards education.  Cultural factors involve societal values, belief systems, and traditional customs. In different cultural backgrounds, there may be differences in the emphasis placed on education, educational approaches, and educational goals. Therefore, educational reforms and developments need to consider the influence of social and cultural factors to establish an education system that aligns with societal needs and values.  Thus, addressing educational issues requires a comprehensive consideration of factors such as school education, family education, the social environment, and culture. Establishing a favorable educational ecosystem requires the collective efforts and collaboration of all parties involved, to create a social environment that supports students' holistic development and lifelong learning.   æ•™è‚²çš„é—®é¢˜é€šå¸¸ä¸ç¤¾ä¼šç³»ç»Ÿçš„è®¸å¤šæ–¹é¢å¯†åˆ‡ç›¸å…³ã€‚ç¤¾ä¼šç»æµçŠ¶å†µã€èµ„æºåˆ†é…ã€ç¤¾ä¼šä»·å€¼è§‚å’Œæ–‡åŒ–ä¼ ç»Ÿç­‰å› ç´ éƒ½ä¼šå¯¹æ•™è‚²äº§ç”Ÿå½±å“ã€‚  æ”¹é©ç¤¾ä¼šç³»ç»Ÿå¯ä»¥åŒ…æ‹¬æ”¹å–„æ•™è‚²èµ„æºçš„åˆ†é…ï¼Œæä¾›å¹³ç­‰çš„æœºä¼šå’Œèµ„æºç»™äºˆæ¯ä¸ªäººï¼Œæ— è®ºå…¶èƒŒæ™¯å’Œç»æµçŠ¶å†µã€‚æ­¤å¤–ï¼Œæ”¹é©ç¤¾ä¼šç³»ç»Ÿè¿˜å¯ä»¥æ¶‰åŠæ”¹è¿›æ•™è‚²æ”¿ç­–å’Œå®è·µï¼Œç¡®ä¿æ•™è‚²ç›®æ ‡ä¸ç¤¾ä¼šéœ€æ±‚ç›¸ä¸€è‡´ï¼Œå¹¶æä¾›å¤šå…ƒåŒ–çš„æ•™è‚²æ¨¡å¼å’Œé€”å¾„ã€‚  å¦å¤–ï¼Œæ”¹é©ç¤¾ä¼šç³»ç»Ÿä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥åŒ…æ‹¬æä¾›å…¨é¢çš„ç¤¾ä¼šæ”¯æŒä½“ç³»ï¼Œå…³æ³¨å­©å­å’Œå®¶åº­çš„å¥åº·ã€ç¦åˆ©å’Œç¤¾ä¼šæ”¯æŒï¼Œä»¥ä¿ƒè¿›ä»–ä»¬çš„å…¨é¢å‘å±•ã€‚è¿™å¯èƒ½æ¶‰åŠåŒ»ç–—ä¿å¥ã€ç¤¾ä¼šæœåŠ¡ã€å®¶åº­æ”¯æŒå’Œå¿ƒç†å¥åº·ç­‰æ–¹é¢çš„æ”¹è¿›ã€‚  æ”¹é©ç¤¾ä¼šç³»ç»Ÿæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªç»¼åˆæ€§çš„ä»»åŠ¡ï¼Œéœ€è¦æ”¿åºœã€æ•™è‚²æœºæ„ã€ç¤¾ä¼šç»„ç»‡å’Œä¸ªäººå…±åŒåŠªåŠ›ã€‚é€šè¿‡ç»¼åˆè€ƒè™‘æ•™è‚²ã€ç»æµã€ç¤¾ä¼šå’Œæ–‡åŒ–ç­‰æ–¹é¢çš„å› ç´ ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥åˆ›é€ ä¸€ä¸ªæ›´å…¬æ­£ã€åŒ…å®¹å’Œæ”¯æŒå…¨é¢å‘å±•çš„ç¤¾ä¼šç¯å¢ƒã€‚        Before addressing education reform, I believe it is necessary to first consider reforming the social system, as educational issues are often closely intertwined with various aspects of the social system. Factors such as socio-economic conditions, resource allocation, social values, and cultural traditions can all impact education.  Reforming the social system can involve improving the distribution of educational resources, providing equal opportunities and resources to everyone, regardless of their background and economic status. Furthermore, reforming the social system can also involve improving education policies and practices, ensuring that educational goals align with societal needs and providing diverse educational models and pathways.  Additionally, reforming the social system can also include providing comprehensive social support systems that focus on the well-being, welfare, and social support for children and families, promoting their holistic development. This may involve improvements in healthcare, social services, family support, and mental health, among other aspects.  Reforming the social system is a comprehensive task that requires collective efforts from the government, educational institutions, social organizations, and individuals. By considering and integrating factors from education, economy, society, and culture, we can create a more just, inclusive, and supportive social environment that fosters holistic development.          æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦ä»˜å‡ºè¡ŒåŠ¨å’ŒåŠªåŠ›ï¼ŒåŠªåŠ›æ˜¯å®ç°å˜é©å’Œæ”¹å–„çš„å…³é”®ã€‚åªæœ‰é€šè¿‡ä¸æ–­çš„åŠªåŠ›ã€ç§¯æçš„è¡ŒåŠ¨å’ŒæŒç»­çš„å¥‹æ–—ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æ‰èƒ½çœ‹åˆ°çœŸæ­£çš„è¿›æ­¥å’Œå¸Œæœ›ã€‚æ¯ä¸ªäººéƒ½å¯ä»¥åœ¨è‡ªå·±çš„åŠ›é‡èŒƒå›´å†…åšå‡ºç§¯æçš„æ”¹å˜ï¼Œæ— è®ºæ˜¯åœ¨ä¸ªäººå±‚é¢è¿˜æ˜¯åœ¨ç¤¾ä¼šå±‚é¢ã€‚  åŠªåŠ›ä¸ä»…æ˜¯ä¸ºäº†æ”¹å˜ç°çŠ¶ï¼Œè¿˜æ˜¯ä¸€ç§è‡ªæˆ‘æˆé•¿å’Œå‘å±•çš„è¿‡ç¨‹ã€‚é€šè¿‡åŠªåŠ›ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥å…‹æœå›°éš¾ï¼Œå……å®è‡ªå·±çš„çŸ¥è¯†å’ŒæŠ€èƒ½ï¼Œæé«˜è‡ªèº«çš„ç´ è´¨å’Œèƒ½åŠ›ã€‚åŒæ—¶ï¼ŒåŠªåŠ›ä¹Ÿæ˜¯ä¸€ç§è¡¨è¾¾å¯¹ä»·å€¼è§‚å’Œä¿¡å¿µçš„æ‰¿è¯ºï¼Œå±•ç¤ºä¸ªäººçš„è´£ä»»æ„Ÿå’Œå¥‰çŒ®ç²¾ç¥ã€‚  æ¯ä¸ªäººéƒ½å¯ä»¥ä»¥è‡ªå·±çš„æ–¹å¼åšå‡ºåŠªåŠ›ï¼Œæ— è®ºæ˜¯é€šè¿‡æ•™è‚²ã€å‚ä¸ç¤¾åŒºæ´»åŠ¨ã€å€¡å¯¼å˜é©ã€è·µè¡Œå…¬æ­£å’Œå¹³ç­‰çš„ä»·å€¼è§‚ï¼Œè¿˜æ˜¯é€šè¿‡ä¸ä»–äººå»ºç«‹è”ç³»å’Œåˆä½œæ¥æ¨åŠ¨ç§¯æçš„æ”¹å˜ã€‚é‡è¦çš„æ˜¯åšæŒä¸æ‡ˆåœ°è¿½æ±‚ç›®æ ‡ï¼ŒæŒä¹‹ä»¥æ’åœ°ä¸ºè‡ªå·±å’Œç¤¾ä¼šçš„åˆ©ç›Šè€ŒåŠªåŠ›ã€‚  è™½ç„¶å˜é©å’Œæ”¹å–„éœ€è¦æ—¶é—´å’Œé›†ä½“åŠªåŠ›ï¼Œä½†æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªä¸ªä½“çš„åŠªåŠ›éƒ½æ˜¯æ¨åŠ¨ç¤¾ä¼šè¿›æ­¥çš„é‡è¦åŠ›é‡ã€‚åªè¦æˆ‘ä»¬åšä¿¡è‡ªå·±çš„èƒ½åŠ›å’Œä»·å€¼ï¼Œä»¥åŠä¸æ–­åŠªåŠ›è¿½æ±‚æ›´å¥½çš„æœªæ¥ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°±èƒ½ä¸ºå®ç°å¸Œæœ›è€ŒåŠªåŠ›ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸ºè‡ªèº«å’Œä»–äººåˆ›é€ ç§¯æçš„å½±å“ã€‚   We need to take action and make efforts; effort is the key to bringing about change and improvement. Only through continuous effort, proactive actions, and persistent striving can we witness real progress and hope. Each person can make positive changes within their own sphere of influence, whether at an individual level or a societal level.  Effort is not only about changing the status quo; it is also a process of self-growth and development. Through effort, we can overcome challenges, enrich our knowledge and skills, and enhance our qualities and abilities. At the same time, effort is a commitment to values and beliefs, demonstrating a sense of responsibility and dedication.  Everyone can make efforts in their own way, whether through education, engaging in community activities, advocating for change, practicing values of justice and equality, or by building connections and collaborating with others to drive positive change. What matters is persevering in the pursuit of goals and persistently striving for the benefit of oneself and society.  While transformation and improvement take time and collective effort, the efforts of each individual are crucial in driving social progress. As long as we believe in our abilities and worth, and continuously strive for a better future, we can work towards realizing hope and create a positive impact for ourselves and others.

These may include cognitive biases, emotional prejudices, moral contradictions, and self-centeredness, among other issues. These flaws can influence our decision-making, behavior, and interactions, leading to unfairness, biases, and conflicts.  Correcting human flaws requires widespread education, cultivation, and increased awareness. One of the goals of education is to help individuals recognize their own limitations and learn to overcome and rectify these flaws. Cultivating critical thinking, an open mindset, and the ability to understand others can help us transcend self-centeredness and biases, enabling better collaboration and coexistence with others.  Additionally, personal self-reflection and growth are also crucial aspects of correcting human flaws. By examining our attitudes, behaviors, and beliefs, we can identify and address existing problems, and progress towards greater maturity, inclusiveness, and morality.  It is important to recognize that human flaws are a part of human nature and cannot be completely eradicated. However, through education, cultivation, and ongoing efforts, we can gradually elevate our level of consciousness and moral character, engaging in society in more positive and constructive ways while striving to reduce prejudice, discrimination, and unfairness.  In conclusion, correcting human flaws is an ongoing process that requires collective efforts from various levels, including education, self-reflection, and social change. Through shared awareness and concerted efforts, we can progressively improve ourselves and society, fostering more just, equal, and harmonious interpersonal relationships.

This includes the pursuit of achievements, power, wealth, and other motivations. These motivations can inspire effort and competitiveness, driving societal development.  However, excessive focus on short-term benefits and quick success may limit the development of creative thinking and innovation. Creative thinking requires time, patience, and an exploratory process. It goes beyond immediate outcomes and emphasizes deep problem-solving, diverse perspectives, and long-term accumulation. If people solely pursue short-term benefits and instant gratification, they may overlook the patience and perseverance required for creative thinking.  In education and the societal environment, striking a balance between short-term goals and long-term development is crucial. Educators and society should encourage students and individuals to cultivate values and qualities such as effort, resilience, patience, and persistence, which are vital for creative thinking and long-term growth. Additionally, the education system should provide diverse learning opportunities and spaces for exploration, encouraging students to think critically and question, and nurturing their creative thinking and problem-solving abilities.  Furthermore, education and society can shape values and cultivate cognitive skills to guide individuals' attitudes towards achievements and evaluations. Grades and evaluations can serve as references and guidance but should not be the sole measurement criteria. More emphasis should be placed on holistic personal development, individual growth, and the effort and progress made during the learning process.  In conclusion, the development of creative thinking requires a balance between individuals' long-term goals and societal needs, while emphasizing effort, patience, and perseverance. Education and the societal environment should provide support and opportunities, encouraging individuals to unleash their creative potential and establishing the right values, enabling the better development and application of creative thinking.

This can result in children feeling constrained in their learning, as they are expected to pursue correct answers and adhere to prescribed standards, while lacking opportunities for exploration, innovation, and personal development.  However, modern educational trends are gradually shifting towards valuing creativity and innovation. Educators are becoming increasingly aware of the importance of creativity and how to provide support and opportunities to foster children's creativity in education. Educators can adopt heuristic teaching methods, open-ended questions, inquiry-based learning, and other approaches to encourage students to think, question, and explore, thus cultivating their creative thinking and problem-solving abilities.  The development of educational systems is indeed influenced by historical and societal factors that have long emphasized achievements and the grading system in the pursuit of excellence. However, modern education is also placing more emphasis on nurturing well-rounded individuals, focusing on their creativity, critical thinking, collaborative skills, and autonomy. The goal of education is not only to pursue grades but to cultivate students' multiple intelligences, adaptability, and innovation capabilities, enabling them to navigate challenges in a complex real-world context.  Therefore, modern education is evolving towards a more comprehensive and diverse direction, aiming to balance knowledge transmission and the cultivation of creativity while respecting individual differences and developmental needs. This requires joint efforts from educators and the education system to provide support and opportunities, allowing each child to unleash their unique creativity and potential.

Indeed, mistakes and rules play important roles in education, but striking a balance between tolerating mistakes and maintaining the constraints of rules is a challenge.  Tolerating children's mistakes is beneficial because mistakes provide learning and growth opportunities. Through making mistakes, children can learn lessons, develop problem-solving abilities, and cultivate creative thinking and flexibility. Tolerating mistakes encourages children to actively try and explore, fearlessly embracing failure, and stimulates their innovative potential.  However, rules and correctness are also necessary. They provide structure and discipline to ensure order and safety. Rules can help children understand the boundaries of behavior, provide a stable environment, and teach them respect for others and a sense of responsibility. Assessing correctness also serves as an evaluation of the learning process, helping children understand their progress and developmental directions.  The key is finding a balance in education. Children need an environment where they can tolerate mistakes in a safe space, receiving support and guidance instead of excessive blame and criticism. At the same time, they also need clear rules and expectations to cultivate discipline and a sense of responsibility. This requires educators to employ appropriate educational methods and strategies to help children understand the importance of mistakes and the purpose of rules, actively guiding their growth and development within the framework of mistakes and rules.  Ultimately, the goal of education is to nurture well-rounded individuals who possess autonomy, creativity, and the ability to adhere to rules and respect others. This requires a comprehensive consideration of the balance between tolerating mistakes and adhering to rules, and the flexible application of these principles based on individual differences and developmental needs of children.

His comment on ADHD is ignorant and offensive. Perhaps his friend had ADHD and, if treated properly, she could have been a dancer and successful in other subjects. If we all left school dancing or singing or painting or playing football then I would have trouble getting a plumber. That was such a breathtaking speech! Actually, it has given me a great flash of inspiration in realizing the true purpose of schools. I mean, schools aren't meant to be a rigid system for producing workers or just to prepare students to go to college. Actually, what's the point there? If that's the way, schools would be worthless and shallow. In fact, it seems to me, as Sir Ken Robinson said, education is about exploring a child's potential and making the most of it. In other words, the point is to help them to flourish from pigeons to eagles so that they can fly their way through life, something that some educational systems need to consider. On the other hand, if one thinks about it, some students are being prepared for today's world rather than for building and changing the future. That's why I agree with him when he says that degrees aren't much important since the true assets that define whether you can be different from others aren't pieces of paper but your skills and talents, such as wonderful creativity.

How schools suppress creativity.   The theme of this topic is that children grow out of creative ideas, since after school they are unlikely to get a job in the specialty they want to choose, and if they do, it will most likely be unprofitable. And such advice may be well-intentioned, but they are bad. Children who enjoy creative activity are forced to study technical sciences only because it is profitable today. Don't do music, you won't be a musician, don't draw, it's not profitable, and so on everywhere. This was formed in the middle of the 19th century, when the industrial Revolution took place. Everyone needed engineers, but few needed artists, musicians and artists of this scale. And that's why the education system around the world is based on the fact that we give priority to mathematics, languages and only a small part of art and music. The second problem is that children are taught not to make mistakes, and this is good, but when a child is afraid to make mistakes, problems arise here. After all, someone who is not ready to make mistakes, is not able to create and think in an original way, he acts according to a template or as he is told. and that's exactly how we run companies, we don't forgive mistakes.

Human beings are creative and resourceful. Can we continue to bottle up education, limiting it via rules, protocols, and maintaining the status quo? There is entirely too much stuff, and means of grappling with that stuff, to keep the same style of delivery of education that apparently is prevalent all over the world. And then suddenly, I have can no longer do algebra in which I did fairly well in the traditional model. But let me explore to learn without having to learn what someone else expects me to learn (put someone else's test on a subject I have just viewed) and I'll struggle. But wow, if I am allowed to explore in my terms, the discoveries are awesome, including the discovery of the creativity and resourcefulness of others.

I totally see his point....unfortunately....this idea that "intellectualism" (I understand it as the ability of dealing with conceptual ideas usually expressed via written and/or oral language) is not important MAY BE EXTREMELY dangerous in modern and future democracies....if we go to the other extreme and decide that this type of education is not important then we would have perhaps a sizable minority (best case scenario) of great musicians and great painters  and a mass of "creative" people without the ability to discern between right or wrong in ethics, politics, etc. and/or without any (or little) scientific/logical/historical tools to understand the world and others around them...

This was a truly remarkable, entertaining, highly amusing, and illuminating talk. Ken Robinson is the type of person you can really appreciate. However, I just wanted to say one not-so-popular point: Psychiatry is not the ultimate enemy to creativity. With the example of Dancer Gillian Lynne, psychiatry may have inhibited her from finding the right environment and flourishing at the Royal Ballet dance school, but with many people psychiatry cultivates the ideal temperament,  sense of well-being, and stability necessary to flourish. You could easily make the (admittedly somewhat ridiculous) argument of requiring everyone to pursue dance school and then the Einsteins and mathematicians who need physics and numbers to flourish are the ones wit the problem. Conclusively, the point is not that "psychiatry is bad", it's that everyone bit of intelligence, just as Robinson said, requires diverse, dynamic, and distinct outlets and environments relative to each person's own uniqueness!

Once, I was caught by the headmistress doodling, she was looking through the window of the door. She came in, told me to give her the book, looked at it and then held it up for everyone to see and mocked me.   Iâ€™m not sick, Iâ€™m an artist. Unfortunately, the school successfully quashed who I am and my parents successfully convinced me that Iâ€™d never be a comic book artist and so I gave up drawing when I was 17. Iâ€™m now 32 and have lost the talent; all I have now is lisdexamfetamine to help me focus in the dead-end factory jobs that I flit between.

My mother told me something once that I found very helpful when in school.  You're shouldn't give your actual opinion or try to answer the question earnestly. Rather, you've got to play a game of "read the teacher's mind" and try and give the teacher the answer that THEY want.

People often say that you shouldn't choose subjects based on your teachers, but that's wrong.  The teacher you have for a subject completely changes how you learn it, and how much you enjoy doing it.  I have ended up really enjoying subjects that I otherwise don't care for simply because I've had a good teacher.  On the flipside, a bad teacher can completely ruin a subject for you that you would normally enjoy, or at least not mind doing.

One of the worst things about school is the wonky distribution of subjects.  For some reason you just get way more time for some subjects than you do for others.  I am failing one of the classes I care about the most and put some of the most effort into simply because I haven't had the time to work on some of the tasks.  Meanwhile, I'm doing just fine on my least favourite subject, English, because we've got two periods of it every day except Wednesday (and the weekend).  It pisses me off how I have to spend more time on the subjects I hate than the ones I actually want to be doing.

English (as in essay writing and analysis) is the only compulsory subject for the HSC.  Maths however, is not.  Maths is essential because you need it to know how much money to pay for your taxes. You need it in your day to day life when buying or selling something. It's absolutely essential for a large number of jobs.  And yet it isn't compulsory. English is.  I've asked a few of my English teachers why English is compulsory and they never have a good answer.  Pretty much:  "Why is English compulsory?" "Because it's important." "Why is English important?" "Because it's compulsory."

I had the pleasure and honor to spend time with Sir Kenneth Robinson in October of 2017.  I sat next to him at a dinner I hosted at my family's restaurant.   He told a story of meeting Sir Paul McCartney, and how they mutually agreed to stop calling each other with a "Sir" prefix since both were "Sirs."  I couldn't stop laughing.  He asked me my favorite Beatle song ("not fair, there are so many. All of them?" I replied)  I finally decided on A Day in the Life as my current favorite.  He told me that use to be his favorite, but now it's Please Please Me because it was one of the few helped launch them into eternity.  RIP Sir Kenneth Robinson (my dinner friend).

I want to comment, but find it difficult to word my thoughts properly. As a future educator, I do agree with a lot of what Robinson said. Schools are driven to be efficient, a common denominator in how to impart what is deemed important knowledge to as many people as possible in as streamlined a way as possible.     A process that in the worst case possible reduces people to a set of A4-organisms, a standard, rather than an individual.   However, how schools are driven that way, is only part of the problem. Other aspects are 1) our view of school and its purpose and institutional mandate, and 2) the politicians that decide educational policy.      My view of school has gone from an institution to just teach children, to an organ that is also meant to impart values - of hard work, criticial thinking, literacy and competence to participate, both as a worker and a member of community and democracy.      However, it is driven with a focus on results and numbers. Children are not primarily taught as members of society and democratic and community participanship, but as workers and participants in a market economy. They are taught in a way that they can give as much money and knowledge to industry as a worker, rather than a person/ and individual.  The way schools and curriculum works, is only part of the problem. To repeat, we as people - as parents, as citizens, and educators - also need to evaluate our own view of schools and its purpose and role, and the the driving policies we (complicitly) help enact.

Many traditional educators miss the point of this talk completely. They think a shake-up in the system will cause problems, or redirect funding, or jeapordize their position. And whilst there is a risk of that, the danger of the kind of stagnation in thinking we see all around us in education is far more dangerous.   Imagination and creative thinking are key in all areas.  Because whilst our knowledge is built on previous learning, it only expands when we ask 'what if?'.  We need more 'What if?' thinking and less 'Here's how'.  And we need schools to be the place children get to try all the things they can't do at home.

My son, before the age of 2, had memorized the entire rhythm and nearly all the letters of the alphabet, and could pick up rhythm's and sounds of words to go with songs at the drop of a hat. But because he didn't always say these little interaction words with adults, and like to say single words when looking at picture books, there was worry over his language skills. He's 2 now and he's learning to sing amazing grace. Ages and stages questionnaires have been always been good, but because he is unique in ways there's a shadow of doubt I can perceive from his daycare workers. I even took the hints and proactively had him attend speech therapist who would visit daycare. The lady made an absolutely ridiculous report for for him, suggested I teach him things he already knew very well, and what was worse she sang old Mcdonald with him and passed on the msg to me to sing old Mcdonald with him... suddenly he hated the song. I pulled him out after only 2 sessions and I'm glad I did, my boy is a truly brilliant creature and I am more the wary this experience. Schools do not kill creativity; they simply don't encourage it.  The same could be said of most businesses.  Institutions are created to serve the average  -- the average student in school, the average employee at work.  The creative individual is by definition exceptional, a round peg in a square hole.    The good news is that creative people are also highly intelligent and learn how to negotiate the maze, even with little encouragement or guidance.  Students with real abilities excel outside the walls of the school by entering writing, art, and scientific competitions on their own and demonstrating talents no school can teach.  Or by working after school.  Or by developing a small business.  It is probable that superior students would excel without formal schooling after age 14 or so.  Many famous men and women did.    Even today, the very best students are autodidacts who teach themselves skills and disciplines beyond the scope of the ordinary school.  What exceptionally talented children need more than teachers are mentors, people who already excel in the relevant field.  Michaelangelo, Da Vince, Andrew Carnegie, John Rockefeller had limited formal schooling, but did have worthy mentors.  Thanks to the teachers' union, there are very few teachers who excel at anything; they aren't qualified to be mentors.  Which suggests we should devise better ways of educating superior students and developing their special gifts.  Making them spend eight hours a day imprisoned in an institution is decidedly not the best way to do it.

Do schools kill creativity? | Sir Ken Robinson   Throughout the speech, Sir Ken Robinson mainly discusses that schools suppress children's creativity. Schools today tend to treat mistakes as an unforgivable fault, as we can see teachers who go furious when we choose the wrong answer by mistake. Mistakes don't precisely signify creativity, but most revolutionary advances have derived from creative ideas thought to be a 'mistake' in that society. As schools make children fear making mistakes, they grow up to lose the ability to create something inventive and ingenious. Moreover, this phenomenon is occurring throughout the whole world. Schools kill children's creativity not only by prohibiting mistakes but by underestimating subjects regarding creativity so as art and dance. The speaker claims that this phenomenon occurs throughout the whole world since most countries consider the ultimate goal of public education is training professors, which requires not creativity but logic. Likewise, creativity is underrated since it is not essential in industrialized society. What jobs require defines people's value. Artists and musicians make less money, so they are less needed. Following society's common demand of intelligence, university naturally changed into the job training center. The presenter strongly argues that this view on education should be viewed differently. For example, ADHD is defined as an attention disorder, yet if we change our attitude toward it, we can find that people with ADHD are talented in bodily activities such as dancing. In conclusion, the author asserts that humans' future depends on whether they adjust their new concept of the education system which can lead to the flourishing of humanity.  Even if the presentation was taken more than ten years ago, his idea is determined to be true. Also, the problem he mentioned is still not settled in Korea. What estimates people's value is the university and the specialty they majored in. Korea has not adapted to the fourth industrial revolution, concerned with computing technology that needs creativity. Exams in schools are taken not to give students motivation to study but to exclude them from success. Students in Korea are not "studying" but "memorizing" technical terms that they never understand. How could they make software and A.I.s though they have never created something new throughout their whole life? It is essential to reconsider the nature of the study.

I was so surprised to find out that I was a mostly curious person who found a lot of the stuff that was drummed down in school and college too difficult, confusing and uninspiring to learn. When I completed my education, I was shocked that reading the same texts made more sense than it did when I was in school/college. Most teachers don't know how to teach. Standardized tests are the benchmark of education in my country and in many others. The natural curiosity and creativity of kids is stifled and they're not encouraged to think outside the box. This one size fits all formula has failed most students and the success of an education system is not that it prouduces a few gifted kids among thousands. It's that it sparks the interest of learning and facilitate it for everyone in a way that works uniquely for them so they all flourish. Thank you so much for this amazing talk. It's one of my favourite ted talls and having read in the comments that you've passed, my heart is heavy. Rest in peace. Thank you for your service to improving our education systems and I wish that this conversation doesn't die out and is being carried forward.

I heavily disagree with him altogether.  Yes schools should promote freedom of thought and even debates-I went to Jewish schools and my teachers always encouraged questions so we'd constantly be thinking.   Why are there intellectual competitions like science fairs? Or even simpler, spelling bees, and geography games? In 3rd grade we were given 1 hour each day to write whatever we wanted so we could be creative.   Every kid wants to be normal and accepted, and not special . In fact that is dangerous because it can make them feel better than others.  I was diagnosed with ADD at 5, I was held back in kindergarten and it was the best decision my parents made  I'm in college and still take medication and it's fine. It's not easy, but its possible, yet I'm the top student in my class not because I'm smarter but I push myself harder because I know I have to, but the result is gratifying.   It's way too extreme to say "oh she likes dancing, she should go to a dance school!" That is the exception, not the rule. Special Ed teachers exist for these issues. A school that can teach the basic subjects but finds ways to promote creativity is a good environment for children.

I love singing, even though I don't have a great voice.  One day when I was 6years old we were practicing singing in school for a special occasion.  The teacher had the class stand in a line and as we all sang  he proceeded to lean into each individual pupil and listen closely to their singing. He went along the line tapping each child on the shoulder and passing judgement saying "you sing" or "you don't sing". He told me don't sing.   I'm 54 years of age now and that is the one lesson I remember from my time at that school.   I'm not shy and fairly confident in my myself but one thing I yearn to do but don't have the confidence.  It's sad when that's the abiding memory I have from primary school

Our education system is terrible, our education system is made to make factory workers during the industial revolution in the late 1800s. Its not made to create creative minds. Schools don't kill creativity. Parents do. The parents who tell school boards which books to ban. The parents who vote for politicians who gut our education budgets. The speech was interesting not only for the people who work or study in the education sphere but also for the authorities who have the power to change something, because the speaker addresses some inner issues of the system and mainly concentrates on how schools can kill the creativity in kids. To support his idea Ken Robinson brings an example of a girl who was written off by the school because of her inability to sit still and concentrate. Later thanks to the girlâ€™s doctor it turned out that the girl is just talented with a unique sense of music and love to dance. That girl, Gillian Lynne, than became a very famous ballet dancer and choreographer whereas her school had all but written her off, mistaking her extraordinary talent for some form of behavioral problem or cognitive impairment. Maybe the school could argue that the girl isnâ€™t following the discipline and concentrating and sitting still is mandatory in class not to distract others, but their approach of writing them off is not right for me. I think this kind of issues arise because the definition and demonstration of creativity is very different for all individuals. However, dear teachers please donâ€™t consider kids with odd behavior â€œoutsidersâ€ because after all if the majority follows a specific behavioral pattern it doesnâ€™t mean that the one with some unique manifestations is â€œwrongâ€.

I really don't understand those people who seem to put all the blame on teachers and educators, where Teachers are the people who help to teach manners, morals, and calculating,etc. and many other things that if you spend your time alone in home you would never learn it. Schools doesn't kill creativity, in fact the environment that you live within is the one who kills it. I mean to be creative you have to start with the base within your home, and to be trained in a certain way of thinking by your own parents first. If you want to discover your talents and creativity you must be noticed, monitored by others in your environment, and encouraged to enhance that specific talent that you have, and when you come to school, school works as a complementary part in your progress. But what people want is to put their kids in schools,they don't ask about their levels, they don't follow up with them at home, they don't give them tasks that focuses on their talents, and they put their children in school expecting them to be graduated as geniuses. Governments doesn't want to open enough schools, Schools' owners are mostly greedy people who wants to have money without giving back extra quality and resources. Truth is, school has us learn how to read, write, do math, and learn information that's been passed down to us generation after generation when in reality, one of the most important subjects has been completely ignored: Ourselves. By ourselves, I mean topics such as: What makes us unique, what is our strengths and talents and how could they be translated into something that can benefit the individual and community, how do we find out what we want to do when we grow up, etc. It is no coincidence why many graduating high schoolers have no clue on what career they want to do or even what they want to major in. If anything, the reason for this is more simple than we make it out to be: They're too busy and used to the routine of getting up and getting to class on time then go home and do homework and rinse and repeat. Unfortunately, this has contributed to the student loan crisis with many kids going to college cause they've all been told that it is necessary for success and then end up changing majors and delaying graduation or choosing majors for the sake of having a major.

Fortunately TEACHERS try to keep creativity alive by doing 12 hour days (including Saturdays) sacrificing, and mentoring, and empowering kids. Nevertheless, while we once had the best education system in the world, today we are listed as 17th--in that range. I want our school system back in full effect. Everything depends on this. The kids are the future. They need the best education in the world again. Why would we not give it to them??

My only problem with this is that there is a reality of the way the world works, and I think that while we want to encourage kids in their gifts and abilities, we also have to help them understand that if what they are really passionate about (eg dance) is not something they can end up making a living at, that that's OK, too.  That its ok to pursue something even if it doesnt make you money (eg if you can't be the leader of the Royal Ballet), and that its also OK to gain a set of skills that might be somehow adjacent to your love (eg teaching dance at a local school or being a physical therapist, etc) that will also allow you to make a living.  Because while I want my kids to pursue their dreams (I homeschool!) I also want them to not feel broke and like they have a set of unemployable skills.  So, I think there has to be a middle ground.  But TOTALLY agreed on the flaws in public school and secondary ed and that's why I homeschool!

I took an English class in college and for once I decided that I was going to take it seriously. I wrote multiple scenes from some of my own stories for essays; arguably the best way to show your skill in writing, sentence structure and more when it comes to English classes. I had a blast writing the scenes out and sent them in. My stories met all of the criteria for the essay assignments, but the professor failed me on the spot simply because they don't accept fictional pieces. I argued against this action and even tried to redo the assignments but they didn't care.   So, if you look at it a certain way, I demonstrated my knowledge, ability, and creativity on advanced writing in one of the most difficult forms of writing, and failed for it.  School is a joke.

Education always lags--but a) the old knowledge and origins of things are fruitful references, and b) the higher the grade level and beyond, the lag closes and is eventually superseded. Saying creativity should be as important as literacy is not an insight. It is obvious. It is already treated that way. Indeed creativity emerges before literacy, and literacy depends on creativity to be there. They are, as most of these things are, intertwined. Dance was always a part of school (gym class, school social activities, afterschool instruction, etc.) until former president Reagan began the steady defunding of public education (30% during his two terms), the process that has all but eliminated the humanities from public schools today. It is still true that you will have a better lifestyle if you are educated beyond high school, even considering modern costs and student loans. Better education costs. It means realigning priorities. It means MONEY. Our tax money. More of it than ever before (as when Sputnik spurred education spending) needs to go to public schools NOW or they will disappear. It seems impossible but yikes, wake up! I know teachers who are already looking for new careers. Unless you want to go with homeschooling, charter "for money" schools, and the like. Unless you want to hang out with folks who treat most expressions of creativity as sinful and evil. Well, knock yourselves out, but that's when creativity will truly die. There are realities to face. This talk isn't about them.

Not to mention that the Trump admin; continues to defund The National Endowment for the Arts, the National Endowment for the Humanities, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and the Institute of Museum and Library Services.

Education is important. Very important! But in my opinion itâ€™s not done right. School teaches us to think realistically. They also teach us to forget our dreams, simply because theyâ€™re unrealistic goals. There are so many people with a college diploma, they have a full time job and they have a decent salary. But how many of them live a happy life?  School should definitely teach us maths, science, history and all those subjects, but it should also teach us how to use or find our talents. Everybody has a talent. Lots of people say â€˜school is a place where you develop your talents.â€™ WRONG! Iâ€™m a musician, and I learnt so much about producing music without school. How? I tried things and I discovered things. I met with people who are like-minded and they taught me how certain things work.   I know, we cannot give extra music, dance, art, acting lesson on schools (luckily there are schools for those things). But at least teachers should teach us that anything is possible and that we should stay curious.   The time we spent in a single school day is huge. A strange and largely pointless talk. Being creative is nice but most of us arent creative or dont care. Finding your niche is nice too, but you cant guarantee you will find it soon or ever.   Random rebuttals:   Primary and secondary education exist to give us all a common context. If kids cant read, write, do arithmetic, or dont know the important moments in history or how government works, they will create a poor society of people who cant communicate or interact with each other properly.  At the optional tertiary level, you can get a liberal arts degree for a fairly holistic education or a technical education if you are more practical-minded. Neither path necessarily leads to merely being a university professor. The professorial path is usually for those who want to give back after a successful career, those doing research, and those professional students too afraid to ever leave school.  There isnt a society on earth or in history that has demonstrated a widespread aptitude for being creative. While the speaker admitted that kids being wrong isnt the same as being creative, he nevertheless failed to give an example of kids being genuinely creative rather than being wrong. Adorably wrong, yes, but wrong nonetheless. Again, basic education exists to put us all on the same page or context. Kids dont know anything so you must constantly teach them what is real or imaginary, right or wrong, cheap or expensive, etc. And like pet dogs, children constantly yearn to learn these things.   As for the dancer he spoke of-totally irrelevant to creativity, but anyway... she was clearly an exceptional case, like steve jobs or bill gates or einstein or any other genius who didnt make waves in academics but blew their niche out of the water. How many parents joining the standing ovation would be happy if their kids dropped out of college to start a dumb business or try to make it in pro sports? What if the dancer had suffered a career ending injury? On the other hand, nothing short of brain trauma will ever take away your education.  The opening and most nonsensical claim: we dont know what the world will be like in 5 years.  Well... obviously? Hardly a new issue. We do the best we can and work within our limitations. This would only be a problem if you didnt teach your students critical thinking, which is actually possible, unlike teaching creativity.  And yea, he totally ignored physical education, so it will continue to be neglected and underdeveloped, so adults will continue to not know how to stand or sit or pick things up properly, how to swim, run, jump, defend themselves if bullied, fall without injury, strengthen their core muscles, etc etc. Never mind that such education would he more effective than medication at lowring incidences of lifestyle diseases and overuse injuries.  Stop kidding yourselves. Education doesnt need a new paradigm or new methods. It just needs a revised and updated curriculum. Few people need more creativity. Nor do we all need to follow some grandiose dream or discover some innate talent. Just perfect what is already in the system.

FlyingMonkies325 The war on 2 fronts is probably the hardest war for a student.  Iâ€™ve seen good kids fall into gangs because their brothers, cousins and friends did it.  Bright bright individuals sitting in jail.  This is where parenting is SUPPOSED to come in.  But not everyone has good parents or even 2 parents.  So the teachers are now having to ALSO fight a war on 2 fronts.  How do we teach kids basic life skills, like respect, AND keep them focused on the actual course content? Well that takes a very special teacher with a big heart and they DO exist but are very rare or tied down to a curriculum.  See those teachers get paid hourly.  The school justifies their existence to its governing board by positive test scores.  If a school shows its passing more students it will receive more prestige and be easier to market towards parents and private investors.  What does this do? It means test scores become the driving force.  And that lovely teacher that weâ€™re waiting for is now forced to TEACH in such a way that test scores are the main objective.  This means that they get handcuffed in how they approach their lesson plans.  They get boxed in.  Combine that with a student whoâ€™s fighting 2 wars and you have a disaster.  What needs to happen is schools need to hire more teachers and Classrooms need to be smaller so that students can be more engaged.  In the USA students are â€œForcedâ€ to go to school.  But in 3rd world countries students are wishing to go to school.  On top of all that, society idolizes the thugs, gangstas, pimps, playas and sexy.  So these people set the bar for student expectations.  They make it appealing and before you know it the student is fighting 2 wars again.  Think about this:  A guy gets out of prison and heâ€™s respected.  A guy gets his degree and heâ€™s a square.  At least in the eye of the streets.  Not in other areas though.  So in the streets we have bad leadership, bad parenting, lack of role models and so many other things a student has to climb out of.  It is no wonder kids turn to slanging dope and gangs.  How do we stop this? Well a good start to your garden is by changing the soil.  Make sure that you get yourself in the right state of mind.  I used to look up to guys like Tupac, Eminem, Bone Thugs n Harmony, E-40, etc... and so now I realize those guys actually offered nothing to me.  They made a profit singing and rapping about change but also told you how to be a gangsta.  Like you said 2 Wars.  How can they claim to fight for one side of the war if they are supplying ammunition for the other?  Pac was a poet in street justice but a gangsta on his next track.  Students come to class crippled by street music.  I know it because it happened to me.  You have to change who you look up to.  Why not choose the highest? God.

It standardizes society.  I always thought one of the coolest things about being in high school was how unique everyone was.  You get out into the adult world and everyone expects you to talk this way, wear this tie,  wear this shoe.  All to create an IMAGE of success that we, as a nation, have come to idolize.

If your an ocean fish in a freshwater like youâ€™ll see ALL the things wrong with it.  Scientists of old PRACTICED science to become scientists.  Today we have laws that bar anyone from PRACTICING medicine until they get their certification.  But the art of just practicing it is lost.  What I am saying is that before you even become a doctor, you have to already see yourself that way.  So whatever it is that you want to do, donâ€™t wait for the school system to tell you what you know, start learning it now and prove em wrong.  Donâ€™t let the ED system tell you what you know on paper.  Take that power back from them and begin learning on your own, outside of that box.  Youâ€™ll be surprised.

FlyingMonkies325 Also, as far as parenting goes and the lack of affection.  It happens in a lot of different cultures.  Some cultures are very stoic and donâ€™t show that type of love. Regardless, whenever people donâ€™t see your point of view or show affection...thatâ€™s when you can go into a dark place.   A lonely void of depression.  You canâ€™t really let yourself go there because if you stare at the dark parts of life all the time, youâ€™ll miss out on the light.  So...try not to let the past dictate your future.  I wish I could say just let it go because it sounds really easy.  But it isnâ€™t.  Just, keep going forward is all I can say from one stranger to another.  Donâ€™t even look back and when you feel yourself looking backwards stop and look forward.  Look up.  Keep going and realize that there are a lot of other people out there who feel the same way you do.  Many many people.  Encourage somebody else.  Thatâ€™s what Iâ€™m trying to do here.  Weâ€™re all running this race of life.  Why not stop and help somebody else along the way.  Especially those who have hit their knee on the same rocks as you.  Stay positive and know that your not alone and somebody greater than you or I loves you and is preparing you for something great. Hereâ€™s how schools ended my creativity. Growing up too maybeeee 6th grade, I doodled on EVERYTHING  My papers would be full of flowers and leaves and eyeballs and it would just be a hot mess, but I still paid attention. Doodling was the only way I could pay attention. If I didnâ€™t move my hand around with a pen on a paper then I just couldnâ€™t process anything. It was like I heard what they were saying and then a second later, I forget it all. My fourth grade teacher was the only one who understood. She would show my work to my parents at meetings and they would ask why she allows me to draw so much on my paper and she said that she would always let me draw as long as I continued to have all As. She said she noticed that I would be a lot more productive whenever we had a language arts lesson because I always had a pen and paper. Come 6th grade. My teachers started criticizing me. They said I would not make it through college with such messes on my papers, and they said my notes look like trash heaps. I had cut down a lot on drawing, and so did my grades. I dismissed my grades as just not being prepared for middle school, and then 7th grade came. I had picked up drawing again. But the criticism was far worse. My math teacher would yell at me whenever I drew because she thought I wasnâ€™t paying attention and that I was trying to impress her. My social studies teacher would give me odd looks whenever we had paper checks, and my science teacher would scowl at me when she saw the condition of my warm up sheets. At that point, I thought there was a problem with me. I thought I had some kind of disease or problem with my head. I forced myself to just stop. Come second semester, my grades dropped tremendously and my teachers are noticing my rapid change in mood throughout their classes. I lost the skill I once had with a pen or a pencil and at that point I thought it was unrecoverable. I tested my creativity and told myself to figure out something to draw and 5 minutes later, I cried. I was so dull. All I could think of to draw was plus signs and glass chemistry bottles.

Â @whatever5575Â  To be honest, I cannot comment on the tests in question because I am not familiar with the way tests are performed in US. Perhaps you do have to much testing. But one way or another, you do need to see whether students actually understand the material or not, and what they understand better and worse.

Â @iamcleaver6854Â  you're right, but the approach is wrong. what percentage of people muddle through school without much understanding of their subject? yet, they've been subjected to countless tests. understanding can be more easily obtained if students ask questions to clear their doubts than acing a test. it makes me wonder if teachers are really interested in their students or just test scores.

Â @whatever5575Â   I think that the solution is that it instead of constant testing, have teachers perform tests at their own discretion for their own sake if they want to know the progress. After each half year have all students write a large comprehensive test to see if they are actually learning something from the teachers. The quality of this test would be of utter most importance, so that teachers don't just teach to the test. Or, to put it differently, the test must be such that teaching for it would equate to quality teaching.
Â @iamcleaver6854Â  that's correct. teach to impart understanding. that's what teachers ought to do. testing is just an instrument and should be of secondary importance.

SnaY Books Books are great.  You have to be very picky about your books though.  Its your time your investing so make sure that the book is written in a way that appeals to you.  Do you like pictures? make sure it has those.  Is it too wordy? pick another one.  It seems oldschool but finding a well written book is like having a one on one conversation with a person from the past or present.  Stay away from books that seem too fluffy with words.  Usually they are aimed at industry professionals OR they are simply writing the book to boost their own ego.  Download samples on kindle or check out books for yourself at libraries or bookstores.  Videos help a lot too but try to get a credible source.  At the end of the day, production is what matters.  Educational degrees just show you went through a curriculum.  It shows your trainable.  But if you could learn, create working examples in a portfolio that demonstrate your knowledge, pick up some minor certifications online through free courses just to have some basic stuff.  You could be good.  Another tip is to Audit a course online.  Auditing means you WONT receive credit but any class like this is usually free.  It allows you to scout the class, take your time with it and not worry about being graded on homework (you donâ€™t need to do hw).  Your just an observer.  And this lets you soak in the information AND also decide if you want to go premium and retake it this time for the cert and with the hw.  I wish more people audited and the school system mentioned it more.  Itâ€™s like a secret almost.  You can even audit real life courses.

I'm an English teacher who is still at the bottom of the totem pole but when I get onto campus, my students gather around me while each one of them is trying to chat with me. I don't go to the office for a while. I just stay there between them while the other experienced teacher usually sneer at my from behind the window. I'm not sure whether this is completely correct, but I've never been too strict with my students. When I'm with them I don't worry to wear my heart on my sleeve. We love and understand each other. Sometimes we don't do homework. Sometimes we watch movies instead of doing grammar exercises. I believe they learn much better this way and I've seen it they do. I just hope in the long run, I'll be remembered as the English teacher who made them smile at class.

If we look at the state of education, technology, and creativity, and how they are connected to the society, we realize the pressure of rethinking some of the fundamental principles of education that will help us to transform the world in a better place for our children to live in. Sir Ken Robinson wanted to prioritize on the kids who need creativity to live a full life. Kids are not frightened of being wrong. Unfortunately, when they grow up, get to be adults, most of them lost that ability.   Intelligence is diverse, dynamic, and distinct. We can imagine our world visually, kinesthetically, or think in abstract terms, in sound or even in movement. Considering the human brain, we can define intelligence as amazingly interactive that doesnâ€™t include interactions coming through disciplinary ways of seeing things. The overall system of public school becomes a protracted process of university entrance that puts significance impact on the self-esteem of many highly-talented, creative people in the different subject area were not valued at school, or stigmatized.

The fourth thing about intelligence: You can't quantify it with a simple number.   Someone who has an IQ of 190 may or may not be helpless when his computer tells him he has a virus. I have attended school for more years than many professional YouTubers and probably a lot of Hollywood video editors. I've written far more hours of music than anyone I know, but I'm clueless when it comes to deducing a fire's cause or point of origin.  If you measure a fish's potential by its ability to climb a tree, it will grow up believing it is a failure.

These are a lot of disjointed thoughts, and a lot of them are good. I don't think education puts mathematics and science at the top of any hierarchy, nor do I think the primary aim of education is to produce professors? Public education teaches people how to be efficient, non-curious cogs in a hierarchical machine that is beholden to the irrational moods of the market, and of course the most privileged subset of students go on to be the people at the top - businessmen, philanthropists (ugh), policy wonks, and yes, professional academics too.   There is no way to revolutionize education in a vacuum though. Education is the way that it is for a reason, and the fact that some abilities are stigmatized and others are fetishized is not down to some kind of flawed logic at all; it is perfectly consistent with the way that our societies are organized.   That is where the problem lies. And a lot of people who have 'made it' under the status quo, who are otherwise intelligent and well-intentioned, are willing to turn a blind eye to that fact because it might threaten their status and the comfortable little bubble they've made for themselves. And that's one of the hardest things to see.

This happened to me as a child in the '80s, I always finished my classwork early, then held back while the slower kids in the class caught up. I had a burning interest in electronics, and I was so excited when it was announced that we would be doing an electronics module within our science class - it turned out I knew more than the teacher, as he was simply reading verbatim from a textbook, without any understanding of how it actually worked, which I tried to explain to him after he was passing off conjecture as fact to the other students, he hated me for this and I was removed from the class. Eventually at 14 years, I started to truant school in order to study in the local library due to my love of technical learning, telling the librarian I was on study leave (here in the UK, you get study leave time to revise your exams, or at least you used to in the '80s), I studied books on computer programming and electronics and filled my brain with so much knowledge of the technical interests I had. However, when the careers officer interviewed me before I left school, they steered me away from the electronics I was passionate about, telling me it would be "very boring work", and tried to interest me in office work. I never lost my love of electronics, just check my channel to see some of the electronic music machines I make, and make music with, yet not a single qualification to my name. School isn't for everyone.

Education is economical driven, and all human activities are economical driven. School did to me, that because of bullying i've turned into a shy and introverted person that keeps getting the creeps at standing with alot of people.  I'm slowly getting better, but talking to more than one person at once makes me receed back into my shell and let the other two talk and eventually excuse me to a 'safe and calm corner'. Also bigger parties (as in more than 10 people) tire me out quickly and i need some time alone to recuperate. Guess it messed up my social sense.  I still have a vivid imagination, but at some point i stopped voicing it. The thing that's bad is, that school doesn't stop bullying. They have a talk to the class, let you stand in front of the class and tell everybody bullying is bad and maybe it'll work for a week. Afterwards it'll be back to the same drag and the teacher kinda give up on it.

There's a negative correlation between grades (marks/notes) in school and creativity. Obviously because the system doesn't want you to be creative. Why? Imagine you give a creative child a task. It will find his own way, create his solution, something new. Well how are you gonna measure this? You have one set of criteria for all students, so you want to measure how precisely they repeat exactly what the teacher had told them before. Just like you have one teacher. Every student has his own needs, talents, interests. Still, the teacher presents the information in one way to all students, who all differ in learning methods^^ I absolutely agree with you, that school should make children creative, because that's exactly what we need! Adaptive, creative problem-solvers! Not people who are smart enough to accurately repeat what they're told and follow orders, and dumb enough to think this makes them smarter than everyone else. (Btw in university the correlation is about zero again, probably bcs of the correlation between Intelligence and Creativity; you cant be creative if youre not intelligent, bcs if youre not smart youre only gonna get where others have already been and thats not the definition of creativity)

The problem now is that schools have doomed everybody above elementary school to almost no creativity. If these creative assignments did show up, all of those students would either be totally stumped the entire class or fail the assignment after giving a bland, unoriginal creation. This means Middle and High Schoolers would have to fully start over at a pre-k level to build creativity again. Why would schools care enough to go through this problem when it's easier to keep spouting out the same school work and keep the same school structure that is training students to grow into mindless beings that follow orders?Â  Most of my teachers agree that creativity should be implemented into a complete revamp of the school system. The problem is that they do not have the power, even if they have the will to go through the pain of the redesign. Some high rank government officials decide how education works, and as long as it worked for most of the population to get jobs before, they see no need to change it now.

Although he has made a point, his remarks on the history of education are not all that precise. Actually the idea of free universal education appeared  way before the 19th century and in many different cultures. The aztecs, for example, believed in mandatory universal education (and when I say universal I mean they also included women in basic education). But also during the Renaissance, many protestant christians, especially in Germany, opened schools for all people to learn how to read, because they wanted people to be able to read the Bible (unifying the german culture and language on their way). The point is, yes, our modern education system is strongly influenced by the Industrial Revolution, but it is only because societies changed priorities along the way.  Also I disagree with this talk because it is implying that music, dancing and painting are the only ways to be creative. In actuality every person that is watching this video in their computers, cellphones or tablets is benefiting from the creativity that some engineer put into creating this technology. And Â¿guess what? the used a whole lot of maths in the process.  My theory is that is not that we are taught a lot of useless things when we should be drawing and dancing instead. The problem is that we are given a whole lot of tools but we were never told how to use the in our every day lives. For example, we surely should use our history lessons when we vote. We should use all that biology knowledge to prevent the spread of diseases. We should use those grammar rules to communicate. We could use that high school mathematics to understand our personal finances and not get in debt. So, please stop saying only because we don't use it to solve our problems.
