Teachers in my high school who want to increase the use of creativity in their class and also increase student's interest in the material are almost entirely shut down in every situation by the teachers who have been teaching within the school for longer. These teachers don't want to see their methods being replaced by someone they see as "Inferior" yet often times these new methods are proven to work better. The best way to get students to be more interested in their school is to actually listen to what they have to say, but in most cases that never happens. In my school district, many of the adults who hold the power to make a difference consider the student's input to be "rubbish". I wish this cycle could end one day but that starts with understanding both perspectives and that is something most adults within our school will sadly never consider doing.

I'm 16, I've been telling stories for as long as I can remember, and I started putting them to paper three years ago. I've always been a "gifted" child--I excelled in math and science, and everyone told me how important and special I was because of my academic achievements, so I thought that my passion for writing was unimportant. I hid it. Even my parents and many of my closest friends had no idea I would pour hours and hours into my stories weekly, or even daily. This year, though, I took a high school writing class, which accompanied my English class. My teacher not only writes but is also very well-respected in the theater community, and has written several original pieces. It was only recently that I had the opportunity to write something creative for his class--a script for an original scene--and by the time I got around to it, I was exhausted from all of my academic work. I wrote the script in under two hours. It was far from my best work, but I simply didn't have the extra time to put into it. After I turned it in, my writing teacher approached me and told me it was outstanding, that he wished he'd had the opportunity to read my creative writing earlier, and that he wanted me to polish it and enter it in a short play contest next year. I'd hidden my love of writing for three years, and almost nobody had ever read, let alone praised, my work, so I was blown away--and I still am. I never dreamed that my "hobby" could be worth acknowledging, but now I was finally being told it was--not by the school system, but by a man who worked in a creative field. In the past few weeks I've opened up more and let more and more people read my work, again, outside of the school curriculum, and I've been told time and time again that I have a promising future in creative writing, if I choose to take it. I've been offered advice, I've been called a prodigy, people have offered to mentor me--it's astounding. And nothing I've shown people has been my best work! But I still have a hard time wrapping my mind around the idea that my creative achievements are more important than my academic ones...because only academic achievement is praised by the school system. I still have to sacrifice most of my time to math and science, because in the eyes of the school system, my writing is not worth a grade. In the eyes of the school system, my passion, my devotion to a creative outlet, means nothing. I'm not the only person I know in this situation--my experience might be somewhat of an extreme case, but I know gifted artists and musicians who are also seeing their talent and creativity squandered by the school system. I've seen it at every school I've ever been to, with dozens and dozens of passionate people. I've witnessed the exact moment when people gave up on their dreams because they were told math and science were more important than what they loved. The school system kills creativity.

This may be the most unpopular opinion in the comment section. But I think the education system is fine, we just need better teachers. Teachers who teach creatively, interactively. I was smartest, I believe, in primary school. Years kindergarten to year 6. You would have one teacher, who would thoroughly get to know you throughout the year and due to that was able to embrace that, and customise your learning experience to bring out the best in you. It was a very one on one experience that nurtured everyone to be the best they could be. This and the fact that everyone felt the same way may be unique to my primary school. Instead of writing a persuasive text to do with the Australian gold rush, we turned the classroom into a court room, dressed up in 1800's clothes, gathered in teams and with excitement pitched our ideas to the class. Our TEACHER had turned what could be a boring lesson into a memorable one that we would remember, and through the various ways we could present our argument brought out the best of our individual talents and made us all feel 'smart' in a topic we may be lost on. This mindset made us confident learners, that weren't afraid to put our hands up, to be wrong. It made us want to learn MORE on topics we may hate. Typically, younger teachers are best. As times have changed extremely fast, the only ones who seem to fit with these modern kids are modern adults: millennials.

This was really powerful, and very true. Schooling was created to prepare kids for industrial jobs. This began in the industrial revolution, when many more workers were needed. Creativity and skills were not required. They just needed someone who could drill a hole, set a pipe, calculate the angle, construct the train's engine, etc. Our grades are even modeled after grades of work or meat. School needs to update. It is in the process of changing and updating, but we should spend more focus on skills, and less on numbers and facts. Yes, we all need to learn these facts, but we also need to hone our intellectual skills. This is what UIL tries to do with their competitions. They try to take the skills that students already have, (writing in my case), and help the students succeed in that field, or with that skill, by putting them against others with similar skills.

Education has become a means to itself. Originally, the idea was to instruct, develop skills, and then test on those skills. It has now become an exercise in teaching people to pass exams. The middle part (actual learning of skills) being omitted as superfluous to the school's objective of achieving good pass rankings. Unfortunately, that means the only thing actually being taught is how to pass exams.   Which, many young people are now extremely good at doing, without actually learning anything in the process. Hence the flood of degree-holders who can't even do basic arithmetic without a calculator.  The multichoice exam has removed even the need to be able to communicate effectively from the curriculum.

Homeschooling. I believe it is good if you want your child to have a more relaxed education. I think some parents get the wrong idea when their kid is struggling at school, they think that school as a whole is bad and they take them out, start to homeschool. But maybe it's just that in particular school? There are many pros and cons of both, but I think going to school is better. Note, the pros of homeschooling is also technically a con, as children aren't learning CRUCIAL life skills that will help them survive at work later one. Lets go back to what i said earlier about it being more relaxed. They are used to constant help, always getting supervised. It's not every man for them self, 'just work it out'. They aren't learning to do things and deal with stress without assistance. School kids are used to being chucked a sheet and expecting to produce an A grade assignment with no help or guide, apart from a marking criteria of what they need to achieve. HS (home school) or private school kids are used to getting a run down of the assignment, getting constant help when they need it. What about when they enter uni/college? If they don't learn how to survive and fight the big fish, they will eat you whole.  A known con of homeschooling is the lack of social skills. I know you can learn how to socialise through groups, there are so many ways other then school. I mean standing up for yourself, facing bullies. You HAVE to face those people everyday, unlike HS kids who can hide from them all they want. It's like a parent constantly getting rid of bacteria from their household, resulting in their immune systems not knowing how to fight it off. Same with bullies. If they are sheltered from negativity, their hearts won't be able to take it when it finally hits.   Overall, HS kids won't survive in the shark tank and will be overwhelmed when situations that require skills you learn at SCHOOL hit them.   Disclaimer: Im not saying all HS kids have these problems, there are ways to get those skills out of school. Not every HS kids is sheltered or guided. I'm saying in general as an OPINION. You are completely welcome to state yours or object as you would in a formal debate, respect me and I'll respect you in return :)  IF YOU'VE READ WARRIORS: To sum it up better, I see HS kids the way the clan cats see kitty pets. But that doesn't mean Bloodclan didn't have the strength to kill Tigerstar, there ARE exceptions.

I agree and support the claim that educational systems need to focus more on creativity and originality in the classroom. We need to prepare our youth for a future of uncertainty, because that is all the future is. No one knows what lies ahead or how the problems and challenges of tomorrow will be solved. It is valuable to learn of the past and know of how things have been resolved and corrected, but if we do not have the creativity to grow and change with the world then we are lost. This does not mean we need to do away with common core and only teach the arts, what it means is we need to rethink the way we teach all subjects. We need to treat every subject with the same level of attention and openness as the next. We need to teach math with the same focus on creativity and technique as art, and teach history with the same attentiveness to storytelling and emotion as drama.   We need to be less quick to judge children who may not be as good at multiplication tables or anatomy, but may flourish in other things. Albert Einstein said it best, â€œEveryone is a genius. But if you judge a fish on its ability to climb a tree, it will live its whole life believing that it is stupid.â€ Sir Robinson echoes this philosophy in a story he tells about Jillian Lin, a choreographer who was able to find her talent at a young age and flourish. Rather than maybe today being told she has ADD and needs to calm down. It is important our educational system is able to find the metaphorical water in which all kids can flourish and grow. Too many kids in school are told they are wrong and believe they are stupid, at which point they are afraid to keep trying and be hurt again. So rather than giving their full effort and letting their passion and creativity flow, they suppress it to protect themselves against failure. This is saddening to see and crippling all over the world as it brings adults into our world who lack the confidence in themselves to chase their dreams and make the world a better place.  A big part of the creative process is producing an original work, and Robinson says nothing original can be made if we fear failure. So how can we be sure to not destroy childrenâ€™s capacity to not fear failure and take chances, while still grading them upon their works. I think the answer lies in the feedback that kids are given as they go through their education. More often than not the response to an assignment focuses more on what was wrong than what was right. Alternatively, I think our education should focus on studentâ€™s successes rather than their failures, to the point that those defined successes can become points to focus on and grow. When a child is told they are brilliant, creative and can invent any answer they want they will go running in that direction. Of course, there are professors and teachers out there who excel in bringing out the creative side of their students but the system as a whole fails here. With ever advancing technology it is a pivotal time in education as new boundaries are reached and the classroom environment is changing. IPads on every desk in an elementary classroom offer endless possibilities for students to open up a black canvas and create unapologetically. Let us push our children to be brighter and better than we are and let them take the world with it. Let us show them to fail fast and fail forward and never ever give up.

Learning is not the same as organized educational institutions. Saying organized religion is "faith" or belief in a God are not the same things. Institutional education - from preschool to PhD - has become a scheme to make money off people in the name of some lofty goal. Any reasoned analysis of the cost vs the output of the educational institutions would show how clear a welfare scheme it has become.  That said, learning, knowledge and creativity are extremely useful in providing a basis for a prosperous society and economy. If public education is an entitlement, the money spent on current educational institutional welfare could be directed toward a home/internet based educational model. It would be far more efficient (less cash per outcome) to have an educational entity that ensured all children had a functional computer and internet connection. There could be facilitators who would develop course goals and individual educational plans and to some extent coordinated learning. What you wouldn't need is a bunch of useless welfare recipients in universities and local school districts. Think of all the overhead that would be unnecessary if you had a model like this. And the facilitators (teachers) would have the resources to ensure they had success. With the savings you could even extend the facilitation to children under 5 without much trouble.

A note from my mom:   I watched this Ted Talk about 10 years ago. This concept of education shaped my whole outlook on homeschooling. After watching it I began a mission to discover each child's gifting and passions. We are a family of homeschoolers. So it was easy to apply this concept to our homeschooling.   My quest was to build each child's education around their passion. So when my daughter Anna was 7 and 8 she majored in the Arts. She learned to read at 9, and write at 11. I have facilitated the learning of each child in the same way, by majoring on their interests and giftings. I am now seeing the beautiful results as eash child follows their passions, and begins to walk in their callings and live out their life goals.  From early days Anna saw herself as an artist. I am so amazed at who she is becoming. But not just Anna, they all are thriving in their gifts, full of confidance, talent and character. Isaac saw himself as a chef, a dancer, a filmmaker. Joe sees himself as a Scientist. They have been developing their talents for years, and I have made it my misson to not let eduction get in the way of their missions.  I have no regrets that I let go of all standards and let them follow their giftings and callings.

I went to school (and did much of my teaching later) in an era when it was commonplace for teachers to express their displeasure at children for getting the wrong answer, but they weren't all bad teachers. Pressured to deliver a formal curriculum within a set time scale, often fearful of principals, parents and district inspectors, such teachers became frustrated and exasperated that their teaching hadn't succeeded, that they hadn't engaged a child in a task, that they couldn't communicate with them no matter what they tried. They wanted to be good teachers but were failing. They had much to learn themselves. A BAD teacher, on the other hand, is easier to define. They are those whose main priority is not the needs or welfare of their students, but their own. Their own ego. Their own career path. Their own comfort and convenience. Their own quest for whatever power they can seize and hold on to. They are the ones Roger Waters sang about in 'The Wall'. A child in error is dismissed at best, humiliated at worst. Most teachers today are not like this. They are dedicated, hard-working, self-critical and keen to learn, and they fall on clips like this one of Sir Ken for inspiration. Bad teachers uses children for their own ends. Good teachers put the children first, leading and joining with them as much as possible on the quest for truth and understanding.

ken robinson says every children is born curious and creative and we are "educated out" of our original creativity but can it be that this highly creative period in our lives is just a stage in our developing brain, meaning that even if school/parents tried to keep us in this childhood creative mindset we end up loosing this kind of creativity anyway ? it seems logical that when interconnections in the brain are being constructed at childhood a curious/creative mindset (free association or divergent thinking type) is required but when the brain wiring process is finished this mindset goes away just like somatotropin is generated to grow our body limbs then it stops to go in the next step of testosterone and estrogen to spark sexual puberty. is there a a "creativity/neuron wiring" hormone generated in the first stage of our lives to help grow our brain interconnections and then it stops letting our brain focus on other important stages in our lives, less creative but more stable in order to have a stable mental environment to raise our own children. an analogy would be seasons for the plant life form : spring is a marvelous season all this life magically sprouting out of nothing and growing at a very fast speed, but life cycle cannot be a continuous spring.  or can it ?

Should we have dropped the atomic bomb on Japan?  A few assumptions: 1. You can't find Japan on a map. 2. You don't know what an A-bomb is. 3. You are unfamiliar with Operation Downfall. 4. You aren't sure of the dates of WWII or who Japan's allies were. 5. Not sure if the depression happened before or after. 6. You don't know about the island hopping campaign. 7. The Germans bombed Pearl Harbor.  How can you discuss that question intelligently if you don't know the basics. Can you write poetry without the alphabet, do anything having to do with finance without being good at math? If you toss your reading, writing, and arithmetic out and focus more on art and creativity then you raise people who are creative but with no skill set for getting a job. Plus most jobs do not need much creativity. 99% of the time you are part of a process. This holds true if you go into business, non-profit or government.

my school, the artistic subjects are valued. its important. we don't have dance everyday in high school. 8th grade. once a week. (forces you to do more, because you need to make the dances) art 4 hours a week. like sculpturing in stone, shoe making, sewing, slamming copper (to make a bowl, a candle holder and such), making a lamp (I soldert this great really technical thing with cubes, led lights. really modern art. looks like a designer piece..I just did that because I liked the image I got in my head) but you also could have drama, cooking or drawing during those hours. music. you are forced to be in the choir. (one hour a week) and music, like a jam b, writing your own song in pairs(OK, like the teacher did help you with the music, since not everyone plays an instrument..so you got like the piano chords, or drum or base line)  learning a song on the guitar.  and now. with the entire class performing one song. with loads of instruments. we do fireflies. I do the gajon. a box you sit on. some of the same sound a drum makes, like the base drum and the snare drum. I don't play an instrument. I'm better with melody than rhythm. but that doesn't mean I'm unable to do that.  yes we also value sciences. but our school slogan is "becoming who you are." I have an adhd diagnosis. my fine motor skills skyrocketed when I got to my school. the creative things help me be able to function in class. instead of eating paper, I now draw on it. as a fidget.  I went to regular education before this high school, in the beginning it was difficult since I had no idea what to create. yes I am and was on medication. doesn't mean you can't fight the effects of it. I actually regained some of my creativity, I never completely lost it. just when it was on demand. Not only does it kill creative thinking, it blatantly displays corruption on the highest levels. Just look up the school-prison pipeline, the reason why you cannot wear hoodies. This is not me calling for complete autonomy, this is me pointing out common sense, that these rules are ridiculous, educators caught off the grid can even tell you how they disagree with it, but you don't see them adding opinions on that on school premises? YOU are in control of how you act on school premises, you are supposed to act respectfully and keep yourself accordingly while in public and in a WORK place setting. School is a work place, it is not a petty echo hall for bullying, teasing, and poor quality teachers who may sometimes lose their composure. However, you are always in control of how YOU learn, not how others want you to learn. My special needs teacher mocked and ridiculed several coordinately impaired children and an autistic girl who asked to go to the bathroom at the wrong time. She even went as far as questioning how they didn't know most of the curriculum since it was so 'easy' in her mind, a month prior before we planned to homeschool, I put a tape-recorder in my lunchbox. After it was found out, they tried to discard the evidence during a parent meeting. after the tape-recorder was brought up, my father showed them it was in his pocket, we had nothing to lose, they asked for it, he declined, we both declined. Corruption at its finest! Our state's law explicitly states that it is perfectly legal as long as I am a party to the conversation, which I was, which is how I got in trouble, for disrupting and wasting '10' minutes of class time after I expressed discomfort with a bothersome student, the parent meeting was regarding this, except instead of blaming the student, I was blamed. This coincidentally was under the time frame in which the recorder was used (2 weeks in),  which resulted in a parent conference for which they tried to take it away. Regardless of the nice facade or all your friends or nice teachers, I have learned that the structure in a school is at stake, ridiculous policies and codes, disciplinary methods, etc, leave parents in fury.

I would encourage to be cautious about making broad sweeping generalizations about an entire profession based on a statistically insignificant sample size.

Here's a tl;dr of what Sir Robinson had to say - or at least, a reiteration for clarity.   What do you think of when you imagine a talented child?  You might be thinking of "talents" through the lens of, "I'm 13 and I'm as skilled of a painter as an art-school professor," or "I'm extraordinarily good at sciences or maths." But you have been misled, my friend, that is NOT what "Talent" is!  The "talent" behind that child artist are skills like steady hands, keen observation, fantastic mind-eye co-ordination, and a ton of learned things on top of it. Things like that are very easy to notice in children. There will always be that one kid that concentrates better than the others, the one that has a keen sense of space, the one that has keener ears than the rest, one that's very sensitive and inclined to personal relations & conflict resolution. But the thing is, talents like that need to be pursued. The brain is constantly changing and neuroscience is proving that its based on the combined systems of "Use-it or Lose-it" and the "Reward System." If you are constantly told to "Stop drawing in class!" and "Your drawings will not help you in life!" and whatever else, you will lose those precious, practiced skills of Steady Hands! - of Observation, of mind-eye co-ordination! We MUST keep practicing it, but our talents are so hard to cling to when we're downtrodden and made depressed by a system that refuses to see how much our "idle drawing" will prepare us for real-life opportunities.   This mentality is why Surgeons are being ENCOURAGED to play video games! Look it up, it's true!  Reflexes, precision, timing, attention to detail, the "In-the-Zone" concentration and so much more are all practiced via video games. But that surgeon likely didn't pursue decades of medical school because education alone got him there. He likely did it because he wanted to be one enough that he practiced until he was good, or maybe, he did it because it was already good at those skills already - and all kids are good at SOMETHING.  But if kids are pursuing their talents, and then often met with: No no, stop that. You there. Tell me what a^2+b^2 means. Can't do that? Welp, look at you, nice failure you'll be. See? You're a failure because you keep doing that... that... that THING that you do!  Does that sound like it would work in the long run for that child? Turning a square into a circle, when it was already a really nice square to begin with? No, no it really won't. And that's Sir Robinson's point. Enable ovals to become better ovals, triangles to be better triangles, while still allowing circles to become lovely little circles.

One of the biggest things I took out of it was that I felt like he was trying to get across the point that everyone is creative, but youâ€™re not allowed to be creative in academics. He made the point that schools prepare children to be college professors RATHER than to help them be creative, as though a professor must be exempt from being able to have original ideas. He also made the joke that during a social interaction, academics are praying for it to end so that they can â€œgo write a paper about it,â€ as if to devalue talking about things in a structured way as a viable outlet of expression. All throughout school, I was one of the few kids that valued academics above everything else. When somebody asked me, â€œwhatâ€™s your hobby?â€ and I responded â€œdoing math or learning about physicsâ€ people would respond, â€œbut what do you like to do for fun?â€ Iâ€™d have to give the answer â€œI play the pianoâ€ instead because itâ€™s a more acceptable answer as a leisure activity. But I could do math the way a â€œnormalâ€ person my age played sports or played video games. I could sit down and solve problem after problem for hours, or rearrange problems and make my own in order to give myself a better understanding of a mathematical concept. And then I could apply that concept to a physical situation to find links between things in the real world that I never would have realized otherwise. I donâ€™t consider myself good at either math or physics. Were I to ever achieve great success in the fields I would not want my achievements to precede me the same way high achievers in the arts often seem to. I would not want my achievements to precede me because I believe that I am not good at the topics, I merely enjoy them, and I wouldnâ€™t want someone to feel like I was better than them just because I enjoyed something they didnâ€™t. Most, if not all people can do math faster than me. I am extremely slow at doing my work, and for most of my life I felt like that was supposed to mean that I wasnâ€™t good at it. Eventually, I even grew to hate mathematics. However, at the height of my loathing in the 10th grade, I discovered that if I tried hard enough, I could comprehend graduate level texts. I was impressed with myself for this, and unlike the other things in life that I had wanted to be good at in order to impress others (which admittedly is why I started doing more complicated mathematics at first), I could do something that I myself could be proud of, and I realized that was all that mattered. I derived great joy from discovering new ideas and the ways they link together, or finding my own new ways to understand something. I have even been brought to tears by the beauty I find in mathematics, as silly as that may sound. I would even argue, physics and mathematics are fields that praise creative individuals, as some of the most notable physicists in history include the likes of Albert Einstein and Richard Feynman, two men who revolutionized physics by working on ideas that everyone had worked on before, but in entirely new ways. So, I'd that no, he is wrong. Schools could certainly be reworked to be more inclusive of children that like to do things like dance, sing, paint, etc., or just be more accepting of students that enjoy different things and learn in different ways in general, but for some, the academic areas in school are the places THEY get to show off their creativity, and in a world that continues to attempt to be more inclusive of those we think are being ignored, we must refrain ourselves from putting the kids we commonly see as â€œuncreativeâ€ or â€œcreative in the wrong waysâ€ on the back burner, in favor of those that we think are being ignored.

The idea of the public school system killing creativity is a valid argument. There currently is more of an emphasis put on academic core classes rather than fine arts classes and other programs, therefore creativity is being denied and the younger generation is not able to freely express themselves. Throughout Ken Robinson's argument, he uses personal experience stories of his family of their transition from England to Los Angeles to help convey the idea that creativity and free expression is being ignored or ridiculed. Robinson also incorporates the story of Gillian of how she was constantly shaking and fidgeting, her mom thought that there was something wrong with her daughter, so she took her to the doctor. Come to find out, Gillian was not sick, she was dancing, so doctor's prescription of medication was to put her into a dance class. Whereas if her mom would have just assumed that her daughter being sick, Gillian would have not been the successful woman she is today. By this, Robinson emulates the idea that people have to move in order to think reasonably. Ken Robinson uses rhetorical devices throughout his speech, including use of pathos, logos, and ethos to advance his argument the United States Public School system is slowly discouraging the creative abilities that our young generation currently has.

I think there are some schools that employ methods such as Montessori, Waldorf, etc. which support creative development, development of emotional intelligence and critical thinking... as was mentioned in the video, holistic learning. Unfortunately these schools are few and far between (at least in the US). Student's with "ADD/ADHD", dislexia and other conditions tend to thrive in these environments along side students without. Much of the information delivered in traditional school settings may seem to be unnecessary, however, I am a believer that exposure to information is a good thing. Knowledge is power. But what is lacking, and I am in agreement with the context of the video, is a delivery method supportive of creative, critical thinking which better equips minds to know how to utilize the information that is being embedded for future use. Creativity isn't only art/the arts... it is the capacity for conceptual thinking and problem solving, seeing situations and objects in various perspectives and dimensions. Again, if these aspects are not taught and fostered then more often than not the other information, facts, and data just don't stick and of course, seem like a bunch of jibberish that will possibly never be used.

Again you are misunderstanding what I'm saying. People who made these great breakthroughs in maths or science or whatever, they did it because they were passionate about whatever it was - they enjoyed it. I'm not saying you or anyone else would get more out of music or history but I would get more out of music because I am more interested in it. And I have to say music is absolutely necessary for entertainment. Maybe you don't understand how broad music is. For example, horror movies would be a joke without music - it adds so much suspense and is absolutely necessary for jump scares. Music does not just include what you listen to on the radio but the entire soundtrack of a movie. You even went as far as to say music holds no academic value which is blatantly wrong. I didn't something click in your head when you, later on, said that you studied it at school. I think you would be surprised at how much maths and science is involved in music and what "sounds good" or interesting. Then you say that becoming a famous musician is highly unlikely and wouldn't have the same long-term impact as a scientific breakthrough. Well again, I disagree. Firstly, it is also highly unlikely for someone to make any scientific breakthrough on such a scale that you feel is important and of course there are lots of smaller breakthroughs which still have impacts. The same can be said for music and musicians, a huge popular musician may have a huge impact on many people and a smaller not as popular musician may still impact others but it's more of an emotional impact rather than something physical. Furthermore, someone who is not passionate about science or maths or any of your so-called "important" subjects are never going to make any of these huge breakthroughs. Finally, your argument seemed more based off the history of subjects like science, maths, economics e.t.c and not modern or ancient history itself. Obviously, the history of the former subjects is essential in understanding them and I would never argue against teaching the history of those subjects for those who are passionate about them (and even for the majority of people up until a certain point in their life). Again maybe history was more useful for you but not me.

+Fidel there are some books everyone should read, as they are ingrained in our culture, the stories repeated in modern form, quotes referred to in politics, academics, and even by comedians and entertainers.  That's why even though I don't love Romeo and Juliet, I still acknowledge it is a VERY important piece of literature to read during your formative years. Likewise, To Kill a Mockingbird and Huckleberry Finn are widely acknowledged as necessary reads. If you are uninterested in the few books that teachers these days manage to squeeze into their schedules between all the standardized exams, you could always read other books outside of class. It is literally impossible for the teacher to choose a book for class discussion that would make everyone in the class happy. Furthermore, Ken Robinson is talking about discovering your talent. How can you do that if you dismiss anything new as boring? You might like reading the Babysitters' club and hate everything else right now, but maybe one day your teacher will introduce you to an awesome book that expands your taste a great deal. You can't develop creativity if you're set in your ways and won't try new things.

look at all the edgy comments saying "OH BOY SCHOOL SUCKS IT DOESNT TEACH YOU ANYTHING BUT BORING STUFF WAH!"  Look. If you want to change education systems, do something about it. Vote for state superintendents and school board members who share your/these values. Express your concerns regarding high stakes standardized testing. Fully fund education so that when districts do their budgets, they don't feel pressured to cut arts programs because of literacy and math (standardized tests again). And finally, if you are a parent, do not be passive in your child's learning because regardless of what happens at school, you have influence at home that is more powerful than you think, to value learning and exploration beyond a classroom or textbook. PS: One person's educational experience is not the same as another. For every person who had a bad one, there is someone who has had a good one. Things are changing but not by themselves. Making generalizations doesn't help the good ones.

I don't really have a problem with the school system in my country. I attend a private school in which we have no choice over the subjects we want to study, but this is so that we can learn more in case our dream career changes or something. In fact, my only problem is that there is an exam you take in 10th grade called the sprach diplom, that measures how fluent you are in german. If you fail that exam, you get expelled. I understand the reasoning for the strict measure that was taken, and the only reason I'm stressing about it is because I'm new and as familiar with german as other students. All I need is some more studying. Now, my problem is that I have nothing Im particularly good at. I excel in every subject placed in front of me, be it a creative or literate activity. Dancing, singing, algebra, geography, history. you name it. The best part is I don't need to study for it to get an 8.5/10. As crazy as it seems, I realise that maybe being able to accomplish any dream or plan I put myself into, doesn't seem like so much of a blessing, but hear me out. I am passionate about anything. I can't help but overthink and love what i do. For the time being, the thing I really want to be is a neurologist. But I don't want to spend my whole life behind a desk studying. But even if I shot to be a singer or writer, I would probably be economically challenged. Not to mention al careers would probably steer me into some kind of stressful crisis at some point, wanting to choose another. I just want to do everything. But sadly life is too short for all I want to do and I have to choose without failure to guide me.

I do think that the education process can kill creativity, but I was lucky to have many teachers who encouraged it instead, even in structured AP classes with specific goals. There was definitely an environment of "There is no right or wrong answer, as long as you can support it." Also, we were often given freedom to do projects in creative ways.  For example, one project was "present a scene of Julius Caesar." One group made a PowerPoint, one group turned it into a live game show, etc. My group wrote and filmed a cooking show based on the scene! We even watched and discussed this TEDtalk in class. One project was to pick a partner and debate two sides of a relevant current issue. The audience could ask questions, and nobody "won," they were just graded o  how much evidence they used and how well they supported their opinion.  Anyway, I guess my point is, the structure of classes may inhibit creativity, but many teachers will go out of their way to help you learn. Don't forget about them, and thank them for their hard work.

Why is it terrible? I was homeschooled by my mother. She taught me reading, writing and math. She would make me color two pages of a coloring book a day, and I expressed myself through building things with legos, playing on the piano (even though I didn't know how), I explored the outside world, became better at math, reading, and speaking than the other "properly" schooled children.  The bad thing was that there was a marriage, and at age 10 we moved away to a different place. The stepdad kept getting in the way of schooling, and we were so poor that I didn't do any schooling for years. All I could really do was read, and my only escape from getting hit or mentally tortured was to spend all day at the library. Every time we moved I'd find out where the library was and read as much as I could. By the time I was 13-14 I was reading at a 12th grade level, where other "school-grown" children could barely read within their own age group, if they even read at all.  In general I was pretty lonely, and friends were rare, but during those difficult years I learned about myself. I gained emotional intelligence rather than intellectual intelligence. When we finally escaped his clutches and I had to start school again (college), it took me 4 tries to get my GED since I had never gone to high school, and once I was actually in college, it took me 2 tries to get my Associate's Degree.  In general, the homeschooling never really ended. I was "officially" homeschooled from ages 3-10, and then unofficially schooled by life from 10-now (26). The only reason I would ever call it "terrible" is because it elevated my mind, my emotional control, my moral compass, personal principles, etc, beyond that of people who went through the "system" and were never challenged by anything or anyone, not even by themselves. Because of that I feel extremely alienated and cannot relate to most people, finding myself to make friends with those decades older than myself (I'm 26 but the friends I make are usually mid-30's-50's, and it's been that way for as long as I can remember).  So no, homeschooling isn't a bad idea.

As a student going into a PHD program in Science education, let me point out where I disagree with this person.1. Creativity should not be given the equal importance as literacy, because Creativity is DEPENDENT on literacy most of the time. Modern creativeness has PRETTY MUCH ALL BEEN DERIVED from pre-requisite knowledge or some background idea and knowledge about a subject. This is especially true in Science. I'll be focusing on science here since I do notknow enough about Language and Arts education, bu have noticed how fundamentally different they are.2. "If you're not prepared to be wrong, then you hamper creativity" completely agree, but by the time we are adults most of us lose this creativity? not necessarily, Infact, most of modern day creativity comes from people who either are adults or about to be adults. especially in Science, an especially in Biology [my field of expertise].Â  because given the world and theÂ  vast body of established knowledge we have today, it will take a significant amount of pre-requisite knowledge combined with the maturity and focus and determination of a determined adult, rather than a child who is suually easily distracted, to manifest true creative ideas.3. We stigmatize mistakes in the work area because mistakes in the work area is counter productive and damages the organization, or has the potential to. There are these things called research departments of many companies that allows you flexibility in creativity, the company pays you to go through that trial and error cycle. In schools, it is about meritocracy. How how can you expect a student that says "coal + air gives us bad gas" and another that says "Carbon + oxygen give CO2" the same way? Especially in science, these details significantly matter. There is a time where mistakes and trial and error can work, but it must work to develop something within the child, not for the child to merely have fun all the time, or else the child will focus on having fun rather than the entire purpose of learning. But during evaluation, you cannot applaud mistakes, that makes no sense. 4. We don't get educatedÂ  out of it. Some of us lose interest as we see that whatever we were trying is INEFFICIENT. Others get bolstered by education to continue their pursuit of displaying their creativity. 5. Are you kidding me? Why dance is not given as much importance as mathematics, or what is called perhaps the most important subject for science? I'm not even gonna acknowledge how stupid that sounds. Needless to say This guy lost legit points with me. 6. The purpose of education is to make people who can make a living based on their education gains, aka LIVE IN THE REAL WORLD. Of course there are other skills, surprised this guy didn't mention ALL THE NUMEROUS SPORTS SCHOLARSHIPS GRANTED TO THOSE STUDENTS WHO EXCELL AT SPORTS!7. OK i'll agree here, this benign notion of "don't pursue that, there's no money in it" sorta needs to change, and something must be there to encourage students to pursue these things, but aren't we getting artists nowadays who took many music lessons,Â  for example Lady Gaga? etc?8.Â  What about the fact that the world is getting more and more educated, problems and situations are getting more and more complex, demands for performance is getting higher and higher, and that's why the demand of better degrees is on the rise? what about work experience? that is one gigantic factor in all this the man doesn't elaborate at all.9.Â  OK, so creativity is based on how different disciplines or ideas from disciplines within the brain come together to form a unique and useful concept oridea. Then how can you be creative without having knowledge in these disciplines?10.Â  "if a man speaks his mind in a forest, and no woman hears him, is he still wrong?" NICE! LOVE THAT TROLLING SLOGAN!11.

I won't say that the school system is perfect, but it's most certainly not as terrible as people in these comments are portraying it to be. Every person is different, and I personally care about maths and science much more than I do painting or whatever. If you have passions follow them, but don't throw everything else away until you know you can. There are people in my year (which I think is 7th grade in American terms) who hate most of school. What schools try to do is open up opportunities for anything. School, a young age, is almost similar to food. You can't fully guarantee that you hate it before you try it. People these days seem to hate learning and it honestly confused me, because everything we do is learned. People didn't suddenly start dancing, they learned how to. If you've made the choice to go get a degree and you regret it then you should learn who you are and what you want before you make these huge life choices.

Â @hueykhalidXÂ  money is based on the trade bargaining system that developed from the original hold/keep model. (Why fort Knox was originally full of gold before we moved away from the gold standard)  In any central system that requires assets or production to be housed and distributed, has fallen back on forms of currency to monitor that system.   People are often quick to point that "money is meaningless" but then don't understand what it developed from. Which was primarily grain storage. The American "hay penny" was an homage to that.   Essentially, all currency is only as valuable as the hold or keep that backs it. And it can only be backed, under a hold/keep and distribution system.  That's how markets are made, it's what trade is based on. Supply and demand, ergo, the supply of your keep and the demand of the community determines how much wheat you can buy for a penny, or a gold coin, or a Drachma could by if you're referencing ancient Greece.   This very structure, and shifting currency further and further away from a tangibly backed standard, (ie away from traditional trade standards where goods and services can be bought and sold with one another and maintains a relative trade value) to what more appears like mathematical gymnastics that ends in a sack of flour being valueless outside of the grocery stores return policy. Unless you can make something with it...  The real question is, how do we bypass this so we don't have to rely on a hold/keep and distribution form of economy from a centralized ruling government?

He's at least partly wrong. The school system in the 'West' is shyte but it can change. At least it is the ONE way in terms of its common, established infrastructure and system that serious, knowledge based, subject based education can occur if teachers are themselves well educated experts as well as trained teachers. This approach is especially needed in this day and age of technology, social media, 'competency' based systems, vocationalism, state and corporate surveillance and all of that somewhat uncritical, shallow identity based politicking that's finding its way into education now (BTW - all things that have been seemingly imposed without popular consent). All kinds of creative pedagogical approaches can still be used if thats what people want - but there is a necessity in the world to educate children "well" as we enter into darker times (you know what I mean). We need passionate people - sure we do - but we need strong critical thinkers who engage with the reality of the world as it is - as well - and ALL students should be able to have an opportunity to take part. All students. regardless of their background should have a right to take part in 'society's conversation about itself' - that's something that is available to certain groups and not others. That needs to change.  The young 'social entrepreneurial' class is addressing public participation to a degree - and its been quite successful - but these are often standpoint/agenda setting based subjective campaigns rather than foundational objective knowledge. In other words (while I agree with many of the campaigns and support them) there is still the problem of objectivity in knowledge and the ability of a student (of any age, gender, race, class) to think through their own decisions, perspectives. Schools can be the means by which the next generation can be extremely well educated and prepared to take on the big challenges in life in they choose to do so. The education has to be available for that to happen. technology, social media, 'cult' of celebrity, self-interest, growing status anxiety - all produced by a money culture that is rarely questioned in a popular context - while all of that exists as the 'norm' in society - then we have to have a counter balance to it - to make a 'real' level playing field - something close to it - so we need well educated, critical thinkers from all walks of life. Schools can take on that role e.g. in the primary and secondary sector.

*****Â I hear ya. I had a teacher though in high school that was very much like the teacher the genius actor Robin Williams played in the delightful movie 'The Dead Poets Society'. He inspired us to express ourselves. To read out loud and write our thoughts, finding the rhythms and building upon that. From his influence in addition to my sister's prodding I joined the Titanic musical airing at my school and got a lead part! I never would have done this without subscribing to their thought! So what I would recommend for you is to give yourself an activity. In a moment where you feel an increase of heartbeat, warming of the ears, etc 'write/draw the concept that came to mind or even anything that is within sight of your eyes'. Let the meaningless 10,000+ thoughts we think everyday float away because they don't really matter at all. What matters are these 5 seconds or so where you think a new thought. Now you can stimulate this reaction at anytime by exposing yourself to stimuli you've never before sought out. Like books or 'The Dead Poets Society' movie. Bookwise I would recommend 'The War of Art by Steven Pressfield. The more you spend time on these 5 second activation modes that spawn new thought, the more you will navigate back to the true north of that original high school you! Peace and Love ^^

I disagree with his point of view. I don't disagree that schools kill creativity. But they kill everything.  From a psychological point of view you almost literally could not design a worst educational system than our school system. There's one thing every human has in common, no matter how smart, dumb, mental, creative, literal, you are. Every person loves, loves, loves to learn! Loves to learn about everything, art, history, science, math, everything, anything. Everyone, I don't care what you say or who you are you love to learn. That's because the human brain is built for one purpose and one purpose only, to learn. It does this very well, and it loves to do this a lot. in order to build a computer that could hold the same information as one human brain it would have to be the size of our sun, with an equally large cooling system. but it still wouldn't be as fast or accurate. Our brain rewards us for learning, makes us happy when we learn something new, its one of the greatest feelings you can experience. But our schools are the best systems that we could ever come up with to make us hate learning. They are the only things on this earth that can make us hate learning. They are soo good at making us hate learning that 1.2 million people drop out of highschool every year in America alone. of those that go to college about 44% drop out before completing any degree whatsoever. If you gathered all of the best psychologists in the world then they couldn't design a worst system of education then the one that we use to teach our children if they tried.  We shouldn't make art a priority we should make changing our whole school system a priority!  The problem is we're stuck in a rut. People hate to change, to try new things. Its like he said we're afraid of failure, so it's so hard to succeed. We found something that works, not well, not efficiently, barely at all, but it works... or so it appears. So we don't want to change it. We're afraid to change it.  Give me a school a good budget and 10 years and I'll have highschool students graduating with a doctorates degree and 3.5/4 minimum GPA's. and the most important part, they will be the happiest kids in the world, they will love to learn and they will beat all of their competition hands down because they will be so good at learning. They will be writing books, reading empirical research, studying everything they can, not because me or anyone else will tell them to, but because they will want to, it will be their leisure activity. instead of a fashion or pop culture magazine they will be picking up science today. They'll be reading books about quantum physics and string theory as a little bit on the side right next to harry potter.  And last but not least, they will revolutionize this world, advance our technology and understanding of reality further and faster than the past fifty years.  Oh and they will love and appreciate art, all forms of art, just as much.  We're teaching our kids how to avoid learning, Psychologists could teach them how to love learning.  If only people were willing to change.

Wonderful presentation and still timely.  'Homogenizing' students doesn't work, and as a psychiatrist I am acutely aware of the number of people who are almost intimidated into finding a psychiatric diagnosis to 'blame for their problems' rather than recognizing their uniqueness and fostering it.  There are some 'Magnet Schools' around now as well as private schools that foster individuality and creativity,  but 'no child left behind' in the public schools certainly went the opposite direction from that not just for students, but for what the teachers had to 'teach or perish'.   Thanks, belatedly, for such an inspirational and thoughtful presentation.

Schools as we know them should be eliminated.  We need resident experts in gigantic libraries also with supervised laboratories to guide the reading and learning of students who should be spending time with books.  Educators are generally entertainers if they are any good.  Educators often are uninformed and teach incorrect information that is massively out of date.  Of course books are also often incorrect because the information is also out of date.  We need places for kids to be together and learn from each other as well as the opportunity to learn independently sometimes with close supervision and sometimes with minimal supervision.  As far as industrial education is concerned, we need to recognize that none of our industries pay enough to support schools sufficiently to have students gain mastery of skills needed in industry.  Industry either pays the full price of college and higher education or they arrange their own training centers.  I don't mean children should go there at two years old.  But children need the opportunity to share with other kids, learn from other kids, study independently and have highly knowledgeable mentors to help students find the books, websites, research articles and computer programs that teach basic skills such as reading, mathematics etc.

My definition of Libraries is quite different than yours.  Libraries are places where relationships have the potential to be fostered and students are not shuttled from one subject to another or from one "teacher" to another.  Schools as we know them cannot do the job of educating and they need to be eliminated and we need to start over.  Little kids can have great learning experiences in Libraries, when there are places where they get attention, love and warmth, the basic ingredients of the love of learning.  Cold libraries also need to be warmed up.  I remember going to my library and it was cold and uncaring but  because I loved to learn, I read everything the library had on Space Travel, Outer Space, Trains and things a little kid might find interesting.  Talk to older people, some teacher's kids, and you will learn that many kids decided early on they didn't like school

We all have different visions.  We certainly need to jettison anything that isn't centered on the needs of the child, including an insatiable curiosity which we can nourish rather than build walls to contain.  I think schools are a big part of the creation of criminality as well.  Kids who are forced to fit where they don't fit get angry and rebel, often to the extent that they self destruct as they try to destroy the box they are forced into.  Our children are the most important reason why we have a society.  All knowledge we have is or could be contained in a library and on the internet.  Kids need to cooperatively and collaboratively investigate who they are, what they are curious about, who is willing to devote the time they are to mastering something, whether it is dance, carpentry, gold smithing, jewelry making, figuring out the universe that surrounds them, comparing value systems around the world and how these value systems have created values to answer basic human questions and offer them the chance to develop their own answers, modify their own answers, consider the value systems of others, and learn to work with older kids and adults as well as younger kids and adults.  I developed a program where high school kids would work with 3rd grade kids to help them to be valued, and challenged.  The jocks in the school decided that didn't create the industrial peons industries need, even those those industrial jobs had left the country.  We need inventors, explorers, lovers, challengers, caregivers, helpers, scientists, optimists and pessimists, as well as many other professionals,  We need to terminate the high tech industry exploitation of foreign born scientists and technologists because we can't get enough kids to want to advance their skills and curiosity in the sciences and technologies.  We need to stop the drug culture that is created by kids to escape the painful life they life in schools being forced to produce tonnage rather than self awareness and an exploration that follows their curiosity.  Genius comes from turning humans loose to dream big and explore.  Of course they need guidance.  But that guidance must not be something that creates resentments.  Give kids the chance to be wrong.  Its a good way to learn.  Keep them safe but let them life a full childhood as they weave back and forth towards their adult contributions to intellectual growth.

Simple solution: publicly funded, privately provided education   - Give every parent a voucher to send their child to whatever school they wish.  - To qualify, schools must teach a minimalist national curriculum. It's a combination of factors, really. The biggest questions really would be, what even is the alternative and to what extent does education lose its value? There are other things that are affected, so it's not just this-and-that answers.  Let's talk about society in general though. You see, large structures are much harder to change than they are to build. Society is no different.  Think of dominoes, where you can put each piece down slowly and gently, but once it becomes large enough, it's hard to go back and change any mistakes you might've made.  A better example would be a 100+ story building. Yeah, building it was difficult, but eventually it needs to be changed drastically to fit the times. Knocking it down would be dangerous and costly, not to mention having to rebuild it while a city now exists around it, where before, it may have been clear. Fixing it bit-by-bit is probably the best way in this case. It's a slow process, especially considering the building may be actively used while being fixed, but it works efficiently enough in many angles.  That's how society is. It's not something we can just bulldoze and start again. We have to fix it bit-by-bit. 10 years has not been long enough, especially since we have other issues going on at the same time. Regardless, just because there hasn't been a change doesn't mean you should just give up and go home. If no one wants to change anything, then nothing will change. Also, that's selfish of you to claim that because you're not giving credit to those who put into changing the system. Carry on and help the best you can. That's all anyone can do.

Had the horrifying experience of mind-numbing public ed. Had two boys and skipped it.... homeschooled them. I can testify personally that the dancing-and singing and drawing, etc.-all blossomed on their own. Cannot tell you how much fun we had with their own "Hollywood" productions and so on. PLEASE people! Think about what you are doing with your own little scientist/singer/dancer/painters.  Our sons were tested with the local school system and beat them every day of the week with less than three hours of formal instruction of the boring stuff a day. And we took off countless Mondays and Fridays as well as every single public school scheduled holiday.  Teach them first to read (easy.... just read to them at first). Then follow up with all the books they would like to read by the ton (hello Internet!). Then start on the math (used a great system of Saxon books... no brainer there). From there you will discover the magic in each one of your children. And to top it all off, no fighting, lying, cheating, swearing, or inappropriate sexual behavior. Unless, of course, you engage in such behavior yourself.  Sir Robinson is quite right... there's a revolution coming. BE THERE!

What we call sound is what we hear. So if there is noone to hear there is no sound! You can read a lot about that problem. --- The joke is about relationships between men and women. As a man he obviously portrays it from the men's point of view. All women think that they are right and men don't understand and don't know a thing - so they (men) are always wrong. ("Women from Venus and men from Mars" is all about that). In his joke there is a man talking. And so if there is no woman nearby - he can't really be wrong because there is noone to think that he is wrong. It all has a connection to another phylosophic qouestion - can someone be wrong in terms of truth and lies - if he is the only one human being? It applies in linguistics especially. If you are the only one who speaks and understands the language - you can never be wrong, because nobody can tell you that you are wrong. And that brings us to another point. If there is noone to point that we are wrong - there are no rules at all. And if there are no rules - there is no language because language is about two things - sound and rules. The problem with the modern day classroom is that it's a highly feminised environment: Sit up straight. Be quiet. Do your work neatly and quietly. Do as you are told. The (mostly) male students who have an issue with being subjected to this environment for 6 hours a day, 5 days a week, are deemed to have "learning difficulties" or be "the class clown". It doesn't help that so much of the curriculum is seen as boring and irrelevant to anything that we'll have to concern ourselves with once we finish school. I remember, even back in Primary school, thinking "This place is designed to teach us how to work in an office one day. But what if we don't plan to work in an office one day?"

+Ian Alvarez The brain is an interesting thing. Try to be creative and your brain will adapt to being creative again just as much as it adapted to being an encyclopedia.

I was more or less on the same boat as you when I was younger. My mom and dad (mostly my mom) instilled in me the belief that I have to get 100% on everything that I did in school. If I got anything lower than a C, I had to endure a torrent of shouting from her. Straight through college, I developed a tremendous fear of failing school because of all that. Even when I went into film school, something that I really wanted to do, I ended up dropping out because I was afraid of getting low grades since I was convinced that low grades automatically meant that I wasn't cut out for the very thing I wanted to do. Ultimately, I ended up majoring history for no other reason other than the fact that I had my best grades in social studies were the classes I did best in; no emotional investment in it whatsoever. It's only recently that I've discovered how these subconscious beliefs have crippled me, and I'm now in the process of rewiring myself to suit what I really want out of my life.

Compulsive public education is an outrage.  Consider this:  Children spend maybe 2 hours per day with their families. The rest is at school and in after school programs. This is a problem.  Children spend up to 8 hours per day sitting in the classroom.  From K-12, students interact primarily with people of the exact same age, experiences, knowledge and skills, yet they're supposed to function properly in the real world?  Students are habituated to following rules and seeking merit badges and accolades from authority figures, rather than creating real value.  The solution is not just a matter of reform. It's not just a top down fix from a bureaucrat in Washington. We need to end this system and allow students and families to explore other options.

School was important maybe 20 years ago, but not nowadays. If we want to know something, we can search it up. We can study it through internet. We can go to college, so we can work at what we were curious about. But instead we're too busy doing things like math (useless unless you want to be a mathematician), sciences (useless unless you want to be a scientist), and philosophy (useless unless you want to have an existential crisis). Schools should still be around, since not everyone can afford paying for internet and devices, but it shouldn't be obligatory. All it does is waste people's childhoods and precious time away, with something that is both useless and stressful for them. The only thing actually important in school is literature and truly basic math (plus and minus). Then, the way most (if not all) countries educate is just straight-up harmful. You have to somehow become a sponge and absorb twenty kinds of different information, only to spew it on a piece of paper to prove you remembered something, rather than learned something by heart. Plus all the pressure from educators, family, and even friends. If schools are to exist, they should be 100% optional (including not needing a school degree to enter college), with no obligatory tests, no pressuring students to do well, and with hours reduced (which already works in finland, which uses 4 hours of school so the children can have equal time to play/sleep/do whatever and learn). So, basically not what we know as a "school".

Knowledge and learning are extremely important, but the words "school" and "knowledge" and "learning" are not synonymous.  Nearly all of us have access to as much information as we can possibly absorb and comprehend, these days, if we want it!  We can learn through books, public libraries, online courses, articles, blogs,  and videos, phone apps, social networks and community sharing programs, and so on.  We are drowning in information!  And we can still create more ways of creating and sharing knowledge.  Our task is to prioritize which information is most important to us as individuals. Homeschooling has amazingly positive outcomes, regardless of parental style or formal education level, and it can work even for single working parents.  I have five children and the older four have all been in school at some point.  Bad idea!  They are now flourishing at home.  Each is unique and wise in his or her own way.  A few months after I pulled my older daughter out of school, at the ripe old age of eight, she came to me and said, "Mom, I'm finally starting to feel like myself again."  And that tells you most of what you need to know about schools.  My husband, a sensitive, brilliant auto-didact, is 51 years old and still bears deep emotional scars from his school experience.  Our baby will be homeschooled all the way!

toastehÂ That can have negative effects. Learning to just deal with what you're given instead of trying to get something better isn't necessarily a good thing. When I was in college I was extremely picky about which professor's classes I would take. I didn't want 'easy' classes, or classes with professors who were reputed to be poor teachers.Â  For the basic GURs the first two years I was in college, when I registered for a class it would just say "staff." So you picked the class that best fit your schedule and hoped for a good teacher. When the professors were announced for the courses, I would go back to the registration office and change my whole schedule to take classes from the professors I wanted, not only transferring out of classes where the professor was had a reputation for being lazy or a bad teacher, but trying to get into classes with the professors who had a reputation for being the most challenging.Â  Most of my peers were content to leave their schedules be, whatever staff was assigned to teach their classes. Some of those professors and courses has a major impact on my career decisions. Who knows what would have happened if I had just settled for whatever staff I happened to get in the first round of registration?

toastehÂ Also, seriously, in the long term, it's not at all an issue. Yes, when you're kids, you might feel a bit out of place, but after starting University no one ever guessed that I was homeschooled and when I told people they were always surprised.

But fact of the matter is that over-protective parents and the isolation kids in the form of homeschooling is more often than not not an effective way for a child to develop social skills. These kids often experience social isolation when introduced because people often find them awkward. And even you started socializing at university; a place where I had some of the best memories and met some of the most fantastic people of my life, including my girlfriend. Suddenly the "popular high school click" was unpopular, and they learned something from that too. All I'm saying is that humans are social creates by nature, introverts as well as extroverts, and we all exchange ideas and discover our identities through socializing with assholes as well as legends. Why limit such exposure?

toastehÂ "But fact of the matter is that over-protective parents and the isolation kids in the form of homeschooling is more often than not not an effective way for a child to develop social skills." No. That is not "fact of the matter." There are no facts whatsoever to support the claim that homeschoolers do no receive adequate socialization. What you stated is merely an opinion and a rather ignorant one at that, as you seem to be going completely off stereotypes. "even you started socializing at university" That isn't even CLOSE to what I said. I said that in University, no one could even guess that I had been homeschooled. Jumping from that to making the wild and ridiculous assumption that I did not socialize until college is just silly.Â  Now, I did say some homeschooled kids feel like they don't fit in. That doesn't mean they don't socialize and it's not terribly surprising or worrying, given that many public-schooled children also feel like they don't fit in. It's a pretty normal feeling for most high school and middle school kids to have at some point or another.Â  "Why limit such exposure?" Because there's nothing to suggest that less socialization is detrimental to a child, and there's plenty of data that proves it's a much more effective way of educating.Â

*****Â I agree with you. But if you don't want to be a biologist why do I have to learn about homologous structures, vestigial organs, genetic drift, and temporal isolation? If I don't want to be a poet why do I have to learn about hyperboles, motifs, alliteration, and iambic pentameter? If I dislike math and don't want to be a mathematician, why do I learn about parabolas, cosins, and logarithms?

flatball2009 I'd like to propose a question to you as a rebuttal to your stance.  If children aren't exposed to these areas of intellectual development, how can they know if they want to pursue that subject?  It's easy to say you don't need it because you don't want to do job x. Â Without exposure to that field though, how can you know if you DO want to do that job?  Obviously you didn't enjoy biology nor poetry.  I'm with you there, buddy!  I partially agree that students don't need to become experts in each and every field, but without exposing them to enough of it to get their heads around it, they may never find that IS something they want to pursue.   At the end of the day, I'm more against our current educational system than for it.  However, reducing it down to the basics that people need to manage a checkbook and communicate isn't enough though to ensure that we stay a successful and prosperous society.  How many doctors have served you that never would have if not for an interest in biology?  How many fruits and vegetables would have never made it to your table if not for botany?  Would you be able to retire or afford your home mortgage if not for the people who found complex mathematics interesting and eventually built the banking industry we rely (too) heavily on?  Would the products you fill your home with get to you if not for the planes, automobiles, bridges, boats, and tunnels that engineers designed?  Each of these fields are just examples where someone found that spark of curiosity and ran with it because of exposure at a younger age.   There are those of us who don't find that spark in school and either find a way to get by or discover the curiosity for ourselves, but why not expose students to areas that can very well open them to opportunities down the road?  Worst case scenario, that student learns that they don't fit into any of the major fields of study covered and they have significantly reduced down what they don't want to do as an adult.

Benjamin OldsÂ Kids should be exposed to every subject. But right when they feel they don't care about the subject, let them not take it. Don't make a child take a course on a subject they don't care about for a whole year.

flatball2009 So, do we have a single teacher per each student so students can jump from one subject to the next at their whim, or do students get to electively skip classes when it's a subject they don't want to take?  For structured school systems to realize that system, one of these two methods would have to be utilized.  The first is economically unrealistic   We can't afford to pay teachers what they're worth at that rate.  Not only that, but there are enough teachers who have no business teaching but are able to keep their jobs because there's not enough available teachers to fill their position.  In that environment, we could never staff the need.  In the second scenario you risk another problem.  What's to keep a student from electing to never attend classes out of laziness, lack of any interest, or other personal agendas.  Ideally, parents would help there, but any public school teacher can tell you that parents aren't accountable enough the way it is.  So in that environment, a student could elect to skip a vast majority of their exposure because they don't believe it matters to them.   Neither of these scenarios result in a society with more motivated and educated students than we currently have.   Though the though is nice in an idealistic world, how would that concept work realistically?

Sir Ken Robinson, you're amazing! You're brilliant AND creative AND hilarious - thanks for the info AND the laughs! :) About school... When I was in first grade, I told everyone for the first time that I wanted to be an author. I loved to write and read then and I still do nowadays. Now that I'm a junior in high school, I don't read as much nor write nearly as much as I'd like. There's all this talk and planning for college and SATs/ACTs. I've been diagnosed with ADD and anxiety and I've gotten the treatment for it. If it weren't for the pressures of school and school drama, I don't think that I'd have ever found out about either diagnosis. I hate to say that sometimes I go to school just to hang out. As an extrovert, I like to see everyone and talk to people. Because of my ADD and anxiety, I find myself sometimes getting in trouble for jokes and talking with friends in class and worrying about the little things. A lot of the classes that you have to take and pass are things that you won't need after your high school/college days. School is the best and worst thing that's ever happened to not just myself, but other people as well. I see it. I see people killing themselves over homework, grades, popularity, friends, appearance, etc. There's a lot of drama that comes with school. School involves competition. Competing can be good, but it an also be draining and even exhausting. You compete against your friends at school. You're competing for the highest grade, you're competing for social status/skills, you're competing for the best look, etc. I hope to be both an elementary ed. teacher and writer someday. please don't kill your creativity - do what your inner kid wants to do
