"Suddenly, degrees aren't worth anything, isn't that true?" "When I was a student, if you had a degree you had a job" (12:38)  So on the one hand the speaker is denigrating the worth of a degree because it doesn't get you a job, and on the other he is wondering why maths is at the top of the hierarchy of subjects and dance is at the bottom. (08:51) Maybe it's becauseÂ Most mathematics graduates generally have jobs, dance graduates generally don't?  Yet the "benign advice" from others not to do music or art because you won't get a job is "profoundly mistaken". (11:50)  This is very basic and very confused.  I am saddened that this is the most watched TED talk, it seems to be little more than a feel good video ("all children have tremendous talents" (03:05) - Do they?, "all children are born artists." (06:20)- Are they?) with few actual attempts at insights/contentions which are:  "Creativity is as important as literacy"Â  I think saying creativity is an important consideration in children's education would have made more sense - as he offers no measure of importance by which the two could be considered equal. This is a banal statement though - it's nothing new.  "Mistakes are the worst thing you can make" In many subjects, including in most jobs, they are - and it's vital not to make them - accuracy is a virtue in many fields.  "The whole purpose of public education [currently] is to produce university professors" No. Those who understand the course the most are most suited to being the professors as they can build upon the collection of knowledge and understanding we currently have. Those that don't understand the course should do the best they can and apply it in real life.  "Creativity: the process of having original ideas that have value" A good definition, along with the criticism of ADHD this is the useful content of the video, the rest of it is telling jokes.

What a great lecture!Â  One statement that Sir Ken Robinson makes is that we are teaching children that it is bad to be wrong.Â  He says that "if you are not prepared to be wrong, you won't come up with anything original".Â  That statement really stood out to me.Â  I personally am someone who is afraid to be wrong.Â  I try to teach my students that it is okay to be wrong, because that is how you learn - you make mistakes - but for some reason I have a hard time teaching that to myself.  I also loved his connection to Gillian Lynne!Â  What a fantastic example of what we are doing to an outstanding number of children.Â Â  It seems that every student these days is classified as ADD, ADHD, etc.. the list goes on and on.Â  And instead of giving these students an outlet through the arts or sports, we medicate them and make them think that they have a disability.Â  In Gillian's case, what is considered a learning disability now is what brought her the greatest happiness and success in life.Â  It's amazing to think about what would not be the way it is today if people like Gillian were told to "calm down".  His last statement is profound yet so simple.Â  "Education the whole being".Â  Let us stop putting the arts on the back burner.Â

The issue with economics is that economics is, at the heart of it, a study of human action (to borrow a phrase from Mises), and human behaviour is inherently subject to some degree of unpredictability, whereas physical phenomena (like the behaviour of stars) behave according to physical laws which are pretty much constant and immutable. So it's (comparatively) easy to throw together an equation which explains all sort of complex physical phenomena (mind you, even so there's a lot that hasn't yet been explained in the physical word), but economic phenomena defy attempts to pin them down with equations. We can try and obtain a passable approximation, but I believe that it's not possible to get it exactly right.

megalibra82Â Well, there are improvements which are pretty obvious - for example, if you lack the rule of law and don't have secure property rights and you want a strong and entrepreneurial economy, well, good luck to you. By not everything is so clean-cut. Take, for example, the issue of free trade. Most economists believe that free trade is, on balance, beneficial for developing countries (and I happen to agree), and very few would advocate out-right protectionism, but then you have people like Joseph Stiglitz who argue that capital controls of some sort still need to exist even if you can freely trade goods and services, and others who believe in a limited form of protectionism for the protection of 'infant industries'. There are success stories on both sides, of course, but there are so many variables that you can never know for sure. And free trade isn't the only issue people snipe about.  The other problem is that many ruling elites have a vested interest in a system that is dysfunctional for most other people. This is a problem even in developed countries - witness, for example, the disconcerting level of influence lobby groups have over American government policy - but it's far more serious in countries like North Korea (to name an extreme example), Iran and Russia etc. So even if we found a magic bullet for all the world's ills, the question is, would there be the political will to fire it?

Having an education system streamlined to university even damages academics such as mathematics, science and English. What can at times be near ludicrous admissions standards of 86%+ for engineering and other science programs leads students not to try harder, but rather to avoid challenge altogether.  The amount of advice for students not to "press too hard" rather than focusing around actually learning tends to be more along the lines of "take only what you can pass with 100%". It is a rather sad sight that students who want to take a course such as chemistry AP will generally need to consider first and foremost the effects on GPA. Students will drop out because in a university level class they got 70% for the first term, At most universities this is the average across all students.Â Â   The effect is inflated grades as more and more people are told to drop difficult courses, which then goes on in a chain reaction as standards become more strict due to students who took the minimum number of classes at the minimum level of difficulty as the other option means risking being derailed from education.

13:21 Recognize the dynamic power of intelligence.  It's quite surprising Sir Robinson exposes that just before interrupting himself to expose supposedly specifications of brain between men and women. This implying that intelligence is mostly static, conditioned by the brain we are born with.  Of course we can't deny data from statistical study of the brain, women may have tendency to dispose of a differently shaped corpus callosum compared to men. But how can we be sure about the significance of those innate differences if the environment, the activities of the person, remodels the brain to adapt to the tasks. Typically musicians are also known to develop this region of the brain. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corpus_callosum#Other_correlations So the influence of gender may and should be contrasted with other influences on which anyone can act on ; so that we may stop redirect people from what they want to be to what they are most certainly capable of. And this links perfectly with the subject : education can have a leading role on self determination, which implicitly means to contradict every stereotypes on categorization (call it gender, social class, race, hair color, anything...)  Robinson seams to mean that education should be about everyone's emancipation in respect of an "inner nature", while it's commonly seen as a conditioning to comply to what society expects. But there is a misconception here, the ones in charge of eduction will still decide for the educated subjects what is their inner nature. Freedom can be seen not only as the pursue of one's goals of personal well being but also as the will to adequate to a situation and contribute to general well being. Yes it's all about individualism and collectivism, about "shaping oneself" without "crushing" it. But can anyone be ethically in charge of this excepted oneself ?

The problem with these kind of talks is that they focus only on the exceptions. What about the 1000 other Jileans who danced but ended up being broke, and ultimately disappointed with their lives. I'm in no way trying to discourage people from pursuing their dreams but I feel everything should be done with the right balance of mind and heart.  The thing about life is that our beliefs, passions and outlook is forever changing because life itself in never constant. So many people believe that life will be full of roses and gardens ONCE they find some dream job, but when they do get it, they relaise it all wasn't as good as they expected and then immediately start setting some other scenario as their promised land.  The wiser thing to do is to make sure you are enjoying your life in the present moment. If you hate your job, then set a logical target income that you can save that can allow you to quit the job to pursue something else. But don't delay life itself. Life may become better in the future or it may become worse you will never know. But this moment right here is the only one where you can say for sure that you can do what you enjoy in some form or the other.  Just to cite my own example. I have left over 15 jobs within the last 5 years in search for something better but every time I found a situation which I initially believed to be blissful quickly turned out to be something I did not expect. Nowadays I'm working on making photography my profession since it's what I love doing. But who knows whether it will work out or not. So instead of delaying my life totally, I live and enjoy my life right now as much as I can and at the same time keep working towards my goal. But this way of living makes me unattached to the outcome of the goal. So if it all doesn't work out in the end, I might be disappointed but not devastated for I'll know I did not give up life totally for this dream. Basically, the idea should always be to live in the present and make sure that we are enjoying to the fullest.

Just had a programming midterm and answered all but the last question. It was a 50 minute exam, I knew the answer to the question but ran out of time to answer it and thus lost marks - as if I never knew it. An extra 10 minutes on the midterm would have allowed me to prove that I knew the subject matter but as it stands now, the result show that I do not, which is false. I also agree with you that if I didn't know the answer to begin with I could sit there and stare at the midterm all day long and I would not be any closer to solving it.  I did really well on my math midterm which was 2.5 hours as I felt I had plenty of time to answer every question. If the midterm was 1.5 hours instead, I would have done poorly as it would not be testing my mathematical knowledge at that point so much as it would be testing my ability to write very fast.

The difference between the speed at which people answer questions lies in their psychology/personality, I believe. People who tend to be outgoing, known as extroverts, have the tendency to answer questions quicker but with less accuracy, but people who are more in their own minds and quiet, namely introverts like to take their time, being extra careful and comparing their choices. Research shows that people can inherit these traits. So to which is smarter: both types of people, energetic and sensitive, have survived since the dawn of mankind, which can explain how useful both types are, and how much we need both types...  I got all that info from this book I've bought, "Quiet: The Power of Introverts" written by Susan Cain, who coincidentally has actually made a TED talk. She talks about what she covers in the book. I really valued all the information, since, I'm a self-proclaimed introvert and like you, I always find myself concentrating hard on one question at a time and making sure I have it right. On my practice SATs I fell a few questions short on each section since they're timed, about 30 mins (I think) for each, and you can't go back. I'm pretty sure I got a good percentage of correct answers on the ones I tried, though...

If always baffles me how exams are such an antithesis for the real world (Â I am going to talk strictly about examinations regarding maths and science, as I have little to no experience of other subjects); you are not allowed for confer with others, you cannot substantiate your answers using source material, and you are most certainly not applying your knowledge in an innovative way. So long as you can remember a standardised list of relevant facts, you will be alright (sometimes you're even given a formula sheet!).  However, employees are not looking for someone who can reel off a long list of facts, as a trained parrot could... they are looking for someone who brings something new to the table; someone who can apply their knowledge critically and creatively in order to solve a problem i.e. to enhance that company's position. The current education system is far too rigid, and focuses far too often on memory tests rather than true innovation.  In my experience, group research projects are by far the most effective way of simultaneously learning/ applying the source material creatively, whilst simulating a working environment, and this is something I would love to see more of within education. Sorry, I once made an abstract assumption (on dextromethorphan, however) one day that all creative metaphor/analogies/allegories were actually wrong. That is that every time someone uses something in place of another for a statement or argument as opposed to proper diction they are[Let's take... idk "cut drugs, your life will fade otherwise" or maybe "all in all, it's just another brick in the wall" as an example]: A) mixing up the meaning (Anyone could receive the message completely incorrectly from lack of concrete idea [ex: fade being notÂ a clear term/slang; just like the definition ofÂ drugs;]); B) not receive the message at all; or C) speaking to the choir (People who understand the message will be the only ones to hear it, therefore the message hasn't spread.) This, to me, applies to all artistic mediums of messages, which they are, we are information gatherers/hosts,Â as well as sarcasm/etc being unclear enough to be rightfully misunderstood (I almost cry for the species which tells each other something that means the 'exact' opposite of what they say). Be reminded of Occam's razor and abstractions of all kinds for this idea.  I'm wondering how this factors into the idea that creativity should be better proliferated through education, if at all, realistically.  Maybe I've just read a little too much on Buddhist non-dualism to understand english anymore; almost as if it's all useless description with no utility more than subjective perceptions of a power of superiority; almost as if death is a shared inevitable and almost as if Descartes' "I think therefore I am" is the only certain truth after all.

On the ADD/ADHD thing: No one knows yet if this is a genetic condition, that is, you're born with it, or if it has environmental causes, like too much television, not enough quiet reading time, not enough exercise, or poor diet. And if it is cause by all those environmental factors, then no wonder there seems to be an epidemic. Anyway, you know if you have ADD if you can't stay focused on the task at hand for about 30 minutes. Taking a break after 30 or 45 minutes is normal. Then back to the task, or maybe a different task. Â Normal people actually display ADD when ill. Â As for hyperactivity, that is rather normal for children, but that too may show up in excess due to the environmental factors mentioned. Â  When we see that an inordinate percent of black boys in the USA have a diagnosis of ADD/ADHD we do wonder if the disorder is genetic...but then these kids come from crappy American Black Culture homes where they are awash in all the environmental factors that may be the cause. Â And add to that all the emotional disorder in that community. Â I do think that if one placed a bunch of ADD/ADHD diagnosed American Black kids in a Buddhist monastery in say, Tibet, that all their symptoms would vanish.

It all comes down to the value schools place upon individual subjects. In the Australian system, this becomes blatantly obvious in the 'scaling' of individual subjects before a student's mark for their final year of schooling is released. Results for Maths and Science subjects are scaled up. The most extreme example is one Maths course where a mark of 40% can get you a scaled result of 90%. On the other hand, subjects like Music and Dance scale down (sometimes as much as 20 points below your original mark). This is because Maths and the Sciences are more valued and students that choose them are perceived as being smarter and working harder. Yes, maybe in the case of some individuals this is true, but the fact that they are making this notion universal perfectly demonstrates what Sir Ken is talking about here. Students that can memorise facts and formulas are apparently inherently more intelligent than those that choose to express themselves. The fact is they are BOTH forms of intelligence that should be EQUALLY valued.Â

I think the biggest reason why school is immensely flawed and why a bunch of little geniuses are not coming out of every classroom is because of the foundation education has built itself upon, that foundation being man-made logic and rhetoric. Now I know a lot of people might label me as crazy for saying such a thing, but its what I think. School makes you think that if something doesn't make sense, to our EXCEEDINGLY limited minds, then that thing is wrong. If such a thing is not evidenced, or in front of you, it is false... But why is the eye more credible than the heart?  If a littleÂ kid were to be a genius, his ideas would probably be illogical because they are unprecedented. But a little kid wouldn't even conjure up such ideas, because the minute he starts school he's taught a method of thinking, that method being "sense" or "logic" but the logic of today is not the logic of 1,000 years ago, therefore, such teachings would be invalid.Â Â   I think the reason world-changing creativity or geniuses is so scarce is because, if someone is a genius, they first have to jump over the obstacle of questioning something (like math, science, theatre, etc.) they were taught was concrete fact their whole life. We develop our children's mindset to grow in boxes, and to deny or deem wrong whatsoever things do not conform, fit in, or align with that intellectual or logical box.Â If something is not aligned with some theory or fact created by some "genius" who lived years ago we tell our kids, or we believe, its wrong. We make kids think like all those "geniuses" who layed down the foundation of science, math, literature, etc. and tell them they're wrongÂ ifÂ they don't but why? They're just humans, they make mistakes, they're not all-knowing...Â We don't teach them how flawed all scholastic subjects, because ALL were created by what seemed logical to a human being... To an imperfect mind. Do you know how many times what's logical to a person is completely wrong? We don't teach our youth, that currently, we know as much as babies who just got out of the womb. In every subject, and in the way we live life.  I don't buy into the idea that were so advanced as a society, because people have been using the same methods to denote whether or not something is right or wrong for a long time, such things don't help us advance as much as we'd like too.  So I think school should encourage kids to not be afraid to innovate education becauseÂ it was created by imperfect minds who easily can create imperfect methods or "facts" this then would allow children to view themselves as equal. In short, school should be about "creating" and creativity.Â  I tell people all the time, and i would encourage kids and students in all schools, to pray and ask for guidance and inspiration (with the only intent of your heart being to help and serve) and through diligence, and scripture study, such will be given. I'm aware most people will disagree, but that's just the way I think, and there's nothing wrong with someone having a different opinion :)  If you'd like to know more about what I believe you can check this out: http://www.mormon.org/

*****Â The way I would teach children (and the way I do try to teach my younger siblings) is by trying to engage them in a way that encourages them to nurture their own interest in education and desire to be educated that as Ken says, we all have. Personally, the Â subjects I dislike most and those that I struggle with most are those that have very strict right and wrong answers, the subjects where being wrong is fatal and I think this is because those are the ones where I (and I think most children in school) was most aggressively chastised for being wrong. I believe school should be a co-operative process and to an extent this is true in certain parts of the world, most predominantly in mainland Europe which incidentally has extremely high academic success. I can say from my own experience if nothing else that I struggle to learn from teachers who are inflexible. I don't think many teachers are inherently unpleasant people, but I think some struggle more to innovate within the restrictions placed on them. If there were no restrictions and teachers were able to find new ways of dynamically engaging their students, I believe both creativity and intelligence would flourish.

McRat1968 Â You misunderstand and perhaps it's my fault for not making myself clear. In fact looking back at it, it's quite certainly my fault for not making myself clear. The assumption 'All teenagers hate school' I agree is not one I can make. I wasn't trying to. I was using a common misconception or generalisation as a basis for argument. If I didn't have that point, the rest of my argument would have no meaning, Without that basic (if flawed) idea, the argument would have been 'Statistically, some teenagers must enjoy school, so there's no real problem...', which I think you'll agree isn't quite what I was going for. I can only apologise if my error offended you in any way, though, having been a teenager for quite some time myself and having known a respectable number of teenagers over the years, I think the sample data I have of their opinions of school, do support the idea that most teenagers find the whole process distasteful, at least while they're in it. In the defense of the current school system. Every action taken by a district, or board is the reactive response to a broad-demand by industry, by people for a systematic process of maximum efficiency and minimal waste.  Society values high GPA scores, high grades. Job Interviewers believe the person with the most valuable piece of paper should get the job, not so much the person themselves. Universities sell their students on the hopes of a stable future through their education-process with little incentive to explore outside the beaten path. High Schools sell their students on the idea of always aiming for A grades because that is what gets you into college. Society focuses on extrinsic rewards and that has transferred to the parents, whom demand the schools, their representatives, and the people in charge now believe in the extrinsic motivation to further subvert the true-learning process we are still trying to achieve with Common-Core. We are telling our kids to go to college, without a true reason why they should other than that extrinsic motivator. STEM major this, Business major that, Medical/Dental school for the next few students willing to step over the bodies of others.  In response to the demand of the community to produce apt people of society, our education system and our way of life has shifted in response to those demands which means a very business-oriented outlook on the schools. This would be fine if the taxpayers are willing to pay their share as well as put in the work needed to help facilitate the learning process. The facts are schools are underfunded, understaffed, and parents expect the schools to raise the children for them. To literally turn children into adults in 12 cycles, ready to take that 6-figure salary. We do not need to envision a future like that anymore because South Korea, Japan, China are the literal embodiments of what it means to push everyone to succeed. And the suicide rates, speaks for themselves.  If the schools are indeed failing, then the community is to blame, the nation is to blame, and you, yourself is to blame for our current situation. When Common-Core kicks off later this year, it will be interesting to observe a situation where preparing every student for college-bound education will be the answer we've been looking for.

By the time I went to school we had a book of log tables. Then calculators were introduced. In my 30's I asked my father what logarithmsÂ  were and how to work them out long hand. Although I have now forgotten the process I can remember with sheer delight the sense of victory I obtained after hours if not days of struggle; this has served no useful purpose in my career. In his eighties my father decided to take up learning the piano keyboard with a little help from his daughter - an accomplished pianist - I gave him a little guidance and he would sit for hours in total concentration working outÂ  right- hand melodies without a great deal of interference from me. The points and questions I am trying to make is as follows: i. Learning is an innate desire in humans. ii. The thousands of years of learning preceding our current civilization was done, so far as is known, by brainpower, skill, ingenuity and a profoundÂ  practical understanding. Current civilization stands on the shoulders of these giants who had to rely on their own wits. iii. Do the benefits of technological computerized aids outweigh the redundancy of the sharpened tool of brain power,Â  understanding and application in real life? iv. Can human progress be defined by the production of robots both human and technological? I am not saying to anyone do not go to school. Â In the modern world, which is most of the world today, human life depends on petroleum, natural gas and coal for life itself. Â The reason we have a huge entertainment sector - creativity - is that fossil fuels provide so much gain that not all people are needed, and the gain is so great that surplus money is in most pockets to pay, like welfare, for entertainment. The non-production oriented "creative types" have to compete for the surplus entertainment pocket money. Â If schools put more focus on the creative types, at the expense of productive types, there would be less pocket money to sustain the entertainers and decorators. If you do not do well in school because you're the creative type, at least be thankful the schools are focused on productive types, as then there is pocket money for which you can compete. And please note, it is rather inconsistent to claim that school kills creativity, when science and engineering are extremely creative, and when we have a glut of entertainment and decoration. Quite apparently school is not killing creativity.

I believe Sir Robinson has a valid point in regards to school systems to a certain degree is killing creativity for certain individuals, however I believe this is due to the paradigm that everyone's goal in life is to earn a large income as possible. This is also true in Asian upbringing (like myself). All my life my parents have told me to go to school, get good grades and get a good job. This has been true for many years for the general population that in order to have a successful career, you need to do well in school in order to get a job. However obviously the supply of jobs are less and less thus the increased demand for higher education. The schools are not purposely killing creativity, they are only attempting to provide the most options to as many students as possible. Obviously this is no longer true, I spent five years getting a university degree only to realize at the end of it that I hated what I studied and I wouldn't be able to get a job with it either, so luckily now I pursue my passion for pastry and baking and am attending a local college which provides such a program. However I was lucky enough to attend a high school that stressed the arts and creativity as much as academics. Otherwise I don't believe I would have ever found my passion. But I wouldn't put the sole blame of crushing creativity to just the school system, it's the whole paradigm in the world where making money is the most important factor in life.

That does not mean that a balance between function and aesthetic cannot be found though. Dance as a job as its own end provides little function. However, if used as a means to an end to promote thought, for instance instead of being on the medication in the anecdote from the video, or, in a means of communication to convey a certain point, what has been created is not simply a dance, but an association to another point of function. Admittedly, I cannot create an example with dance, but can do show with another art form. Consider a theatre classroom setting in which one must act and convey human emotion and intensity. Now, consider that means of theatre used to convey an idea on say, global warming. If one is interested in theatre, they shall use the medium to promote the meat of the idea, causes, effects, and amount of factual validity to it, while creating a story. The human mind does not simply react to information alone, and the arts are in just about every form of worthwhile communication to this date. To ignore that flair that is given to our knowledge, will only serve to make us less adept at our jobs.

ilikrandomness However adept people may be at their jobs and however useful artistic flair may be in carrying out their tasks, you first have to get a job (for which you need basic skills) and for the vast majority of employment creativity is nil. Â The customer (e.g. everyone else) wants cheap and efficient, the ability to be creative, experiment and make mistakes in the real world, just gets you sued and fired. The balance between function and aesthetics may be a sought after goal, but speaking for the UK, our education system is not achievingÂ function for millions of students, so what price aesthetics.

I agree. An entry level position that requires basic skills will not require a large amount of creativity, and does not tend to promote it. However, an entry level position is just that. It is intended to give the employee the basic skills and experience in a workplace on a template on how to conduct business. The patent office, or fast food establishment, or any sort of menial labor does not take too much mental power, and therefore not much creativity. (btw before going further, I would like to note that I am aware that many people keep entry level jobs for a long time and live off of those wages. My heart goes out to them.) However, if education is intended to promote skilled employment, that is a different situation. A lawyer, or engineer, or even middle management in the entry establishments will require a decent amount of thought process to achieve their goal. That goes along with creativity when put into practical application. As the arts promote creativity, and different forms of thinking, being able to use an argument, or make a more efficient blueprint requires knowledge and creativity. And as for the risk factor, many establishments will not go along with risk if there is not some sort of approval process, and those that will are likely to have risk involved anyway. If schools in the UK are focusing too much on the arts, than that is a legitimate issue. However, giving them less of a prevalence than they deserve is one as well.

Jay FlippenÂ Expanding your learning capacity by "learning extra stuff" will be helpful in the future, as [learning specific things] will contribute to different areas of your brain and will benefit those areas such as: memorization, recognition, using logic to determine what is true and what is not, and other useful areas.

Learning to memorize the "extra stuff" even changes your brain so that you're able to learn more in the future.Â  These anti-memorization and anti-test arguments are usually not based on well designed studies.Â  Knowing lots of things in general will actually expand the possibilities of creative thought.Â

Yeah, that might be the way to go for some things, but I think of those approaches as second and third steps that follow an initial round of traditional studying/memorizing.Â  I guess the problem is that what you're curious about now is just a function of what you've already seen (and maybe some natural abilities).Â  A kind of forced exposure to the details of different topics might lead to new areas of curiosity.Â  It's also a way to come up with novel ideas by analogy . . . On the neurobiology side of things, you do forget a lot of the specific content you memorize in school, but at the cellular level, the act of memorization changes your brain's ability to memorize things in the future.Â  Memory research is still too underdeveloped to know anything for sure, but there appears to be a BDNF driven pathway that might have a lasting effect on the ability of dendritic spines to form new synapses following studying/learning . . . and, oddly enough, following cardiovascular exercise.Â  Making your brain store and recall any information (and for some reason running a lot) will have lasting effects on your ability to learn anything.

People who are denying or disagreeing with this, I (for the most part) respect you're opinions as much as anyone elses, but you couldn't be more wrong. Having spent my entire school career studying music I know that this video speaks truth. Creative arts people were a massive part of my upbringing, and I've met loads of talented and intelligent art students, but the schooling system in the UK just does not treat them that way. Many simply give up and choose to go through the system studying "academic" subjects like everyone else...GCSE's...A levels...Degree...Job (hopefully). Josh GrahamÂ Hi! I'm happy to hear you're doing well. I know people who have done well though in school they did not do so well. However most people who do well did benefit from their 12+ years of, as you call it "memorization". For instance, chess champ Anand has a degree in accountancy. And the list goes on. But if you read books and know case law, then you have memorized, so it makes no sense for you to be demeaning the art and practice of memorization which like a muscle, improves and becomes more beautiful with exercise. I did mean to say that creating is a higher level skill than memorization, but I do want to emphasize that any creation of real value comes only from one who has already "memorized" that which has come before. So we can look to Beethoven, who created the current modern world of music taken serriously, only after he had mastered (what you call "memorization") Haydn, Bach, Mozart, Verdi & Rosini. In Beethoven's time, and still today, no one could dispute his creations, as none could top him. *****Â I'm a bit astonished by your question. Take for example any music composer. Such a person has memorized various scales & chords & depending on genre, much or all of notation and all the common arrangements. Take for instance the late Leonard Bernstein, conductor & composer. When conducting he knows, that is, he has memorized, all the charts used by all the players and, like all good conductors, knew when just one wrong note was played by one player. Â Or on the other hand, engineers memorize a mountain of knowledge so they can dash out a new design. I have a hard time thinking of a credible creative endeavor that does not rely on a huge database of knowledge. Storytellers know tons of stories and rules for storytelling as well as spelling and grammar. One can just throw blotches of paint on a canvas...but did you know many of the more successful of such attempts are rule based? Even Fung Shui is rule based. Also Manga.You have to know (have memorized) the rules to apply them on the fly - occassional reference to books is allowed, but often the creator knows the book quite well and knows (has memorize) exactly where in the book to look up some data. Come on now, you know this, why pretend otherwise?

Josh GrahamÂ To read one must have memorized many word definitions, rules of grammar and word structuring & phonics to make quick sense of unfamiliar words. Â To read something and understand and interpret one has to have memorized enough of the background material to make sense of the new material and to judge it's validity. One does not spend the years K-12 in memorization only - integration of the memorized knowledge is also taught and is expected. Those who learn, really learn - which requires much memorization - will outpace most of those who don't and enjoy a more comfortable and fun life, as comfort & most fun costs $. Can public education be improved? Always. However we are also missing a little of what Sir Robinson touch upon, the "strip mining" of our kids. I'm not saying being marketable or having a job isn't important, but if we let corporate interest dominate our educational policy, we are doing just that, spitting conforming commodity widgets.

Also, if a schools sole purpose is to provide a livelihood for said persons, what is the other less realistic option? No fundamental education at all? We have a public school system, imperfect as it is, to provide at least a minimum functional level of education to a population who could otherwise not afford to educate their children. The purpose of schools is this role, and depending on the makeup of teachers and personnel, has varying degrees of success.

The fundamental principles of school today came to us from 19th-century Prussia, i.e., compulsory attendance and school records (the latter being part of the "dossier system" of keeping a lifelong file on citizens).  There will never be any major change in education so long as it's compulsory and state-run. You will never break the stranglehold of the Dept. of Education and the teachers' unions.  A new emphasis on creativity will occur only via homeschooling and online. E.g., "Khan Academy."

Mortimer J. Adler, Jacques Barzun, and Alfred North Whitehead have all written extensively on the problem of creativity and education. If you look into the history of education in the US, you'll see the push to make public education revolve around math and science, with the arts and humanities subordinate, correlates with the history of increasing centralization and government control over the whole process. Creativity can never be central in a government-run system because it's a threat.

Very persuasive speech, however, this speech lacks something very important: a viable alternative. If our education system is broken, how should it be fixed? Should public schools be allowed to more flexibility in their curriculum? Should we stop equating our children's education (and what we pay our teachers) with a standardized test? If I teach open-ended science lessons, they do little to boost the standardized test scores, which makes the public view me as an ineffective educator.

Has our society in general forgotten how to have fun on our own, without being passively entertained? Was this a purposeful thing, to 'engineer' better workers for the industrial revolution. Whether this has influenced our education system or if it is the other way around, remains to be figured out. But changing our education system could be the way to turn things around. Having been homeschooled, I can assure you we are all not socially awkward. I've never had any problem fitting in, and often when other kids find out I was homeschooled it comes as a surprise to them. I agree that homeschooling is definitely not the solutions, because it really all depends on the parents, and I was fortunate enough to have good parents. I chose to go to highschool because I wanted to be around more people, and I did just fine.

For the same reasons you don't homeschool, I didn't homeschool my children, except that I rarely give answers. I ask guiding questions, teach how to find information, how to think. It's hard work, and most students don't appreciate it. They just want the answers.  You still have a life-time ahead of you.... go for it! From this day forward, be a lifelong learner, and take charge of your own learning. Sounds like you're on your way already! Good luck.

Moroever, creativity means just doing something divergent, novel, and (some argue) is valuable to others. You can think outside of the box in plumbing, for example, by creating a new method for streamlining water or repairing piping. However, the speaker (while not explicitly stating it) seems to imply creativity is akin to participating in music, dance, and art within schools. Creativity can be attained in any domain.

The one things this speaker misses is the fact expertise is a major component of creativity (Amabile, 1983). Expertise encompasses everything that a person knows and can do in the broad domain of his or her work. It doesn't matter we acquire this expertise, whether through formal education or practical experience. Herb Simon calls her "network of possible wanderings," the intellectual space that she uses to explore and solve problems. The larger this space, the better.

Test success in the US in many non-academic fields, is becoming moot. Employers are shifting towards candidates with working knowledge regardless of their degree (I have two friends in the tech industry, both who are self-taught, some of the best in their field didn't even finish college, namely Bill Gates and Steve Jobs). There's also an over saturation of people with degrees often are working for minimum wage if they have a job at all, so academic success is starting to mean less over time.

Also, because graduation hinges on passing the test, it hurts students who aren't test takers, but otherwise are good students with reasonably high grades.   My graduating class was the experimental group for our state. Imagine year-round lessons taught to steer students towards passing the ACT/SAT/GED/GRE/etc. and little time for flexibility in other lessons. (cont.)

The tests implemented in the past decade were originally intended to force failing classes & their teachers to reach that standard. This has been hurting teachers who teach to inspire a love of learning in their students. There's a few articles online. I can't find the particular one I read, but it's heartbreaking to see that passion destroyed because the board wants consistency & control, when they should be targeting ill qualified teachers & bringing them up to standard. (cont.)

The school curriculum has way too many rules.  It doesn't allow teachers, professors, and students to be creative.  For example, if a teacher tells her students to draw a vase, you might get a few pictures that are really creative and out of the ordinary.  However, the vast majority of them will look similar.  If you tell students they can draw whatever they want to, then you're going to get students to think outside-of-the box.    Even art classes can kill creativity.

Multiple choice tests kill creativity.  In the real world you won't have the answers right in front of you.  You're going to think of all the possible solutions (that makes people think outside-of-the-box).

@tchaccaroo   There is an approach to home-education called 'un-schooling'. It's called that because it does not try to replicate 'school' at home, but rather to harness a child's natural drive to WANT to learn by encouraging hir interests, and along the way elaborate on certain aspects which us contemporary adults 'think of' as subjects [maths, physics, writing, etc]. There are unschooling groups in Australia - google it, there's heaps of resources/info.

Does school really kill creativity ? Let's take my high school as an example. I am allowed to choose two classes of my six; I must take some foreign language, health, and P.E., but beyond that i am free to choose courses that would fill courses for more than three years of education. So far i have taken graphic design, web design, and programming (which i like best), all classes that gave me tasks but allowed me to choose how to accomplish them-are theses classes not developing my creativity?

My basic point then is that the presentaion is utterly groundless. Schools aren't killing creativity, there's plenty of creativity in any conceivable field. What schools are factually killing is the solid education foundation that enhances and actually supports creativity. Hence the document complaint of employers that they can't get employees that can, e.g., read and write even after college. I was forced to pass postgraduate students that couldn't write a decent paragraph.
Yes, problems with mass education are easy to identify but practical strategies to change it without doing more harm than good are notoriously difficult to implement.

I agree. Correct me if I'm wrong but I never argued one's superior (in fact I believe you're supporting my view). I, like Mr. Robinson believe that one's emphasis is severely lacking in the education system. Like you pointed out, balance will allow for the greatest things. Where the balance is is arguable. Any such balance is not possible under the current curriculum however.

Mutual exclusion is often the result of education argument when the reality is that its not one or the other but both. We can teach a dog some very useful things without it being creative. This is one way of separating training from education. For most humans both are important and the key is getting the balance right at the right time and the politics is in arguing were that balance lies.

"Leaving creativity intact," as you put it, does not require sacrificing academic skill, nor does he condone sacrificing academic skill. He's not promoting pure educational liberalism - he's saying that forcing academics (and penalizing mistakes harshly) without helping creativity is bad, and adding some "educational liberalism" would help. "when you teach science, inevitably you must first memorise and learn existing established principles"  I speak from experience as a science teacher. The first task of a science teacher is to get their students to understand & use the scientific method & the first step in that is teaching students how to ask question. The arts has just as much "memorisation & learning established principles" as any other discpline. Example: music classes are filled with "5 finger exercises" & the like.

"Stress causes physical/mental/emotional unhealthiness"  No, too much or constant stress causes unhealthiness. However, stress is & should be part of life. No one can or ever will live a stress free life. Students need to learn how to deal with & cope with stress. I would even say they need to learn how to apply stress to themselves, ie. to self-motivate & push themselves to reach their goals (which is & can be very stressful at times).

"creativity in the form of art (original ideas of value) needs to be a part of every academic subject"  I agree with this 100% We need to break down the barriers between the various classroom subjects & integrate cirrucula. Example: use dance to teach social studies & history (the culture context of the dance), physiology, physics (momentum, gravity, etc), and physical education. Math can be combined with history & biology to teach epidemiology & the history of the Black death in Europe.

"It was the technology you worship that caused global warming... "  1) I don't "worship" anything. 2) Yes, technology has also created H-bombs & weaponized anthrax. Technology is not always good or not always used well. But, I was not talking primarily about technology. I was talking about science. They are different. But if your point is that on the whole technology harms mankind, I find that an interesting statement to be made using a computer over a global communication network.

"You are proof of what happens when children are indoctrinated in public school"  Indoctrinated in what, exactly? The belief that societies & individuals are better off when diseases are eliminated (ie. polio, small pox, etc.)? The point is not that all students should become professional artists, nor even that they should be encouraged to.  The point is that developing multiple intelligences makes everyone better at everything they do, and that lays the foundation for a much less dysfunctional society.

Sports are analogous to the arts. Many people enjoy playing sports, but only a tiny percentage can make a living at it. The focus on rare success stories misleads millions of young people, who tend to greatly overestimate their chance of making it in glamor jobs. There has never been a labor shortage in the worlds of sport and art, so it's hard to see the problem with our current schools. They hardly need to push more kids into glamor jobs.

Every culture has art, even the poorest. Why? Because the arts are fun. But only a tiny percentage of people find a way to make money doing what they enjoy. Robinson cherry-picks one of the success stories to make his point, but for every rich artist, there are thousands waiting tables. The vast majority of people lack the talent to make a living by entertaining the vast majority of people.
